('95', 0, 2, 3, 71) PATNA, April 30, 1947
('95', 0, 3, 4, 93) MAHESH, I went through everything [you sent me].
('95', 0, 3, 5, 142) I like you.
('95', 0, 3, 6, 154) You can come when I am here, not in my absence.
('95', 0, 3, 7, 202) Ask me after my return.
('95', 0, 4, 8, 226) Blessings from
('95', 0, 5, 9, 241) BAPU [PS.] Do as Mridulabehn says.
('95', 0, 5, 10, 276) I do not need [anyone knowing] English.
('95', 0, 5, 11, 316) One should know well the Devanagari and Urdu scripts and Hindi as well as Urdu.
('95', 0, 5, 12, 396) It is essential that one should be [aware] 1 of the potency of the charkha and the handloom and should also know Bengali and Sanskrit well.
('95', 0, 5, 13, 536) My handwriting has come out badly due to haste.

('95', 0, 7, 15, 626) 2. LETTER TO FRANCESCA STANDENATH
('95', 0, 8, 16, 660) [April 1947] 2
('95', 0, 9, 17, 675) SAVITRI 3, I was delighted to receive your letter.
('95', 0, 9, 18, 726) Indeed I did not know you were alive.
('95', 0, 9, 19, 764) But then there is saying that God keeps those whom he wants to keep even through most stormy weather.
('95', 0, 9, 20, 866) The news you heard that I was going to the Frontier was wholly wrong.
('95', 0, 9, 21, 936) But where I am is worse than the Frontier.
('95', 0, 9, 22, 979) And yet one rarely knows what is good for us and what is bad.
('95', 0, 9, 23, 1041) Therefore if we knowingly put ourselves in the hands of Almighty, whatever happens must be deemed good.
('95', 0, 9, 24, 1145) And I try literally to follow that precept.
('95', 0, 9, 25, 1189) Now that you have commenced writing you should continue to write as often as you can.
('95', 0, 10, 26, 1275) 1 One word is illegible here.
('95', 0, 10, 27, 1305) 2 As in the source.
('95', 0, 10, 28, 1325) This was in reply to the addressee’s letter dated January 23, 1947. 3 In Devanagari

('95', 2, 1, 2, 2908) 5. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 2, 2, 3, 2936) NEW DELHI, May 1, 1947
('95', 2, 3, 4, 2959) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, It is only twenty days since I had left Delhi.
('95', 2, 3, 5, 3028) But even as I went I had a feeling that I might have to return soon.
('95', 2, 3, 6, 3097) But my place was then in Bihar and Noakhali and I could not stay back even for a fortnight.
('95', 2, 3, 7, 3189) That was why I went to Bihar.
('95', 2, 3, 8, 3219) I had told you that I was Jawaharlal’s prisoner and would return whenever he sent for me.
('95', 2, 3, 9, 3309) I have come back as soon as I received the summons from him and Kripalani.
('95', 2, 3, 10, 3384) You will be happy to learn that when I went to Bihar people left me in peace.
('95', 2, 3, 11, 3462) They did not bother me on my way.
('95', 2, 3, 12, 3496) I slept in peace, I was not tired and could even do some work.
('95', 2, 3, 13, 3559) But that was not the case on my return journey.
('95', 2, 3, 14, 3607) People created noisy scenes at every place.
('95', 2, 3, 15, 3651) It did not occur to them that an old, infirm man like me should be left in peace, and his sleep should not be disturbed.
('95', 2, 3, 16, 3772) Today I felt exhausted as I was not able to sleep well.
('95', 2, 3, 17, 3828) Even so, I did work during the day, because it is work that sustains me.
('95', 2, 3, 18, 3901) I cannot live without work; but I could work very little.
('95', 2, 3, 19, 3959) What I really cannot stand is shouting by the people and the slogans they raise.
('95', 2, 3, 20, 4040) Through you I wish to convey to all people that they should not greet me with noise and should not raise slogans.
('95', 2, 3, 21, 4154) It would be all right if the people gathered at the railway stations if they wished, for, if they came, some collection would be made for the Harijan Fund.
('95', 2, 3, 22, 4310) But they should not make noise.
('95', 2, 3, 23, 4342) I wish to tell you what I did in Bihar.
('95', 2, 3, 24, 4382) The work done there is considerable.
('95', 2, 3, 25, 4419) Shah Nawaz has installed himself in a small place.
('95', 2, 3, 26, 4470) He is now meeting with success in his work.
('95', 2, 3, 27, 4514) The Muslims who had fled to Asansol under duress have come back.
('95', 2, 3, 28, 4579) They had to undergo too many hardships at Asansol.
('95', 2, 3, 29, 4630) They realized that people could be comfortable only in their own place.
('95', 2, 3, 30, 4702) Their children had grown so emaciated that their bones were sticking out.
('95', 2, 3, 31, 4776) They were not looked after in any way there.
('95', 2, 3, 32, 4821) Now these children are provided with milk.
('95', 2, 3, 33, 4864) It is impossible to get fresh milk because our cattle have gone dry.
('95', 2, 3, 34, 4933) Hence, these children are being given powdered milk.
('95', 2, 3, 35, 4986) Powdered milk does not have the vitamins fresh milk has.
('95', 2, 3, 36, 5043) But the inherent nutritive property of milk is preserved in powdered milk.
('95', 2, 3, 37, 5118) After their return from Asansol these children have regained health because of the powdered milk and they have started putting on weight.
('95', 3, 0, 1, 5256) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 3, 1, 2, 5296) Then there was the question of rations for the adults.
('95', 3, 1, 3, 5351) How to provide food for so many people who had come back?
('95', 3, 1, 4, 5409) They were afraid to go out and buy the rations themselves in a place where they had been persecuted.
('95', 3, 1, 5, 5510) The Government arranged to have the rations sent to them.
('95', 3, 1, 6, 5568) But their Hindu neighbours protested saying that the Muslims were their guests and they would themselves bring the rations to their houses, and that it was not necessary for Government officials to trouble themselves on that account.
('95', 3, 1, 7, 5802) In another place, where Muslims had been killed in large numbers, those who had survived were hesitating to return.
('95', 3, 1, 8, 5918) Some I.N.A. men escorted them so that they could get over their misgivings.
('95', 3, 1, 9, 5994) On seeing the I.N.A. men going with them some Hindus told them that they need not take the trouble.
('95', 3, 1, 10, 6094) They were going to serve these Muslims.
('95', 3, 1, 11, 6134) They would protect them even if it meant death.
('95', 3, 1, 12, 6182) The I.N.A. men said that they were obeying the command of their General, and they could not go back.
('95', 3, 1, 13, 6283) Then the Hindus pleaded that they would not always be mad.
('95', 3, 1, 14, 6342) Earlier they had really lost their heads.
('95', 3, 1, 15, 6384) Was it any bravery that ten thousand people should come together to kill one thousand?
('95', 3, 1, 16, 6471) They would never do it again.
('95', 3, 1, 17, 6501) Thus the Hindus drove away the fear from the hearts of the Muslims, and encouraged them to return to their homes.
('95', 3, 1, 18, 6615) As a result the Muslims themselves asked the I.N.A. men to go back.
('95', 3, 1, 19, 6683) I am confident that if the situation in Bihar turns out well, the trouble continuing in various parts of India would come to an end.
('95', 3, 1, 20, 6816) All I wish to say is that all of us have to be courageous.
('95', 3, 1, 21, 6875) But I hear that people are now indulging in dastardly acts in Delhi also.
('95', 3, 1, 22, 6949) Every day crimes are being committed insidiously.
('95', 3, 1, 23, 6999) Shameful things are happening in Dera Ismail Khan too.
('95', 3, 1, 24, 7054) 1 They have not yet ceased.
('95', 3, 1, 25, 7082) People ask me what has happened to our signatures.
('95', 3, 1, 26, 7133) Why is peace not being established?
('95', 3, 1, 27, 7169) I did not affix my signature after meeting and consulting Mr. Jinnah.
('95', 3, 1, 28, 7239) The Viceroy insisted that I should sign the appeal.
('95', 3, 1, 29, 7291) I asked him what authority I had to sign the appeal.
('95', 3, 1, 30, 7344) I am not even a four anna member of the Congress.
('95', 3, 1, 31, 7394) What good would my signature be?
('95', 3, 1, 32, 7427) I am a small man.
('95', 3, 1, 33, 7445) Of course the Quaid e Azam is a big man, his signature would carry much weight.
('95', 3, 1, 34, 7525) But the Viceroy told me that Jinnah Saheb was keen on my signature.
('95', 3, 1, 35, 7593) He was not ready to affix his own signature unless I affixed mine.
('95', 3, 1, 36, 7660) He said that if I gave my signature, he would at least know what Jinnah Saheb really meant.
('95', 3, 2, 37, 7752) 1 Murders, arson, loot, destruction of property and conversions on a large scale had been reported in Dera Ismail Khan and Hazara Districts.
('95', 4, 0, 1, 7893) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 5
('95', 4, 1, 2, 7932) Thus I put down my signature.
('95', 4, 1, 3, 7962) I will not discuss what followed.
('95', 4, 1, 4, 7996) Signing a peace appeal is nothing new for me.
('95', 4, 1, 5, 8042) All my life I have done that and I continue to do it.
('95', 4, 1, 6, 8096) But Jinnah Saheb’s signature is a great thing.
('95', 4, 1, 7, 8143) If all Muslims are under Jinnah Saheb’s influence, they must now abide by his words; for he has signed on behalf of the Muslims.
('95', 4, 1, 8, 8272) But have I given my signature because I am a Hindu?
('95', 4, 1, 9, 8324) I have influence over none.
('95', 4, 1, 10, 8352) I belong to no party.
('95', 4, 1, 11, 8374) I belong to all.
('95', 4, 1, 12, 8391) If the Hindus of Bihar act in frenzy again I shall fast unto death.
('95', 4, 1, 13, 8459) In the same way, if the Muslims in Noakhali lose their heads, I shall lay down my life there.
('95', 4, 1, 14, 8553) I have earned that right.
('95', 4, 1, 15, 8579) I belong to the Muslims no less than to the Hindus.
('95', 4, 1, 16, 8631) I belong to the Sikhs, Parsis and Christians in the same measure.
('95', 4, 1, 17, 8697) I may be crying in the wilderness, but whatever I say would be on behalf of all and addressed to all.
('95', 4, 1, 18, 8799) But Jinnah Saheb presides over a great organization.
('95', 4, 1, 19, 8852) Once he has affixed his signature to the appeal, how can even one Hindu be killed at the hands of the Muslims?
('95', 4, 1, 20, 8963) I would tell the Hindus to face death cheerfully if the Muslims are out to kill them.
('95', 4, 1, 21, 9049) I would be a real sinner if after being stabbed I wished in my last moment that my son should seek revenge.
('95', 4, 1, 22, 9157) I must die without rancour.
('95', 4, 1, 23, 9185) But why in the first place would a Muslim kill at all when he has been asked not to do it?
('95', 4, 1, 24, 9276) But the thing is that they have still to realize that in politics force cannot avail.
('95', 4, 1, 25, 9362) People ask why our signing the peace appeal is not having any effect.
('95', 4, 1, 26, 9432) Why are the Muslims still not contained?
('95', 4, 1, 27, 9473) Why are Dera Ismail Khan and the Frontier Province rocked with violence?
('95', 4, 1, 28, 9546) Dr. Khan Saheb and Badshah Khan tried to stop it but the people there claimed that they belonged to the Muslim League.
('95', 4, 1, 29, 9665) If the people of the Frontier Province, even as supporters of the Muslim League, do not honour the words of Jinnah Saheb, I would venture to suggest that it is his paramount duty to leave everything and work to restore peace.
('95', 4, 1, 30, 9891) Why is he not following that course?
('95', 4, 1, 31, 9928) Is he going to achieve Pakistan by following his present course?
('95', 4, 1, 32, 9993) If he wishes to have Pakistan, let him have it by adopting peaceful methods.
('95', 4, 1, 33, 10070) When someone achieves something by force, it is snatched away from him by a greater force.
('95', 4, 1, 34, 10161) Jinnah Saheb’s idea of achieving Pakistan by force can never succeed.
('95', 4, 1, 35, 10231) But I want to ask even the Viceroy why he is not able to do anything after getting the signatures from both of us.
('95', 4, 1, 36, 10346) Why does he not take me to task?
('95', 4, 1, 37, 10379) Why does he not take Jinnah to task?
('95', 5, 0, 1, 10416) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 5, 1, 2, 10456) Hindus and the Muslims continue to fight even after that, if the Sikhs continue to fight, the British should step aside.
('95', 5, 1, 3, 10577) But what would you do if the British continued to stay here?
('95', 5, 1, 4, 10638) You say you would take up arms, but the British are not going to be frightened by your arms and give you anything.
('95', 5, 1, 5, 10753) Even now, they are not talking of granting us freedom because of our arms.
('95', 5, 1, 6, 10828) They think that India has shown a new way to the world.
('95', 5, 1, 7, 10884) That is the reason why we are getting our independence.
('95', 5, 1, 8, 10940) As it is, there are too many people in the world who meet force by force.
('95', 5, 1, 9, 11014) They even talk of killing two for one, let alone one for one.
('95', 5, 1, 10, 11076) But, I say there will never be any peace even if you kill not ten but a hundred for one.
('95', 5, 1, 11, 11165) There is nothing brave about dying while killing.
('95', 5, 1, 12, 11215) It is an illusion of bravery.
('95', 5, 1, 13, 11245) The true martyr is one who lays down his life without killing.
('95', 5, 1, 14, 11308) You may turn round and ask whether all Hindus and all Sikhs should die.
('95', 5, 1, 15, 11380) Yes, I would say.
('95', 5, 1, 16, 11398) Such martyrdom will not be in vain.
('95', 5, 1, 17, 11434) You may compliment me or curse me for talking in this man ner; but I shall only say what I feel in my heart.
('95', 5, 1, 18, 11543) While you are listening to me patiently, I shall only express my heart’s anguish and ask you to be courageous and not get frightened.
('95', 5, 1, 19, 11677) If someone wants to scare us into surrendering anything we would part with not even a cowrie.
('95', 5, 1, 20, 11771) If he comes to persuade us we may give him even crores.
('95', 5, 1, 21, 11827) If you cannot show such courage and if the Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs all become mad, whatever the British may do for us and whatever they may grant us, will never remain in our hands.
('95', 5, 1, 22, 12011) What we want to achieve we must achieve through persuasion.
('95', 5, 1, 23, 12071) If we learn this art all will be well with us; otherwise there is absolutely no doubt that India is doomed to perish.
('95', 5, 1, 24, 12189) [From Hindi]
('95', 5, 2, 25, 12202) Prarthana Pravachan—Part I, pp.

('95', 6, 1, 2, 12273) 6. TALK WITH MANU GANDHI
('95', 6, 2, 3, 12298) BHANGI NIVAS, NEW DELHI, May 1, 1947 The members of the Congress Working Committee are unnec essarily insisting on my presence.
('95', 6, 2, 4, 12426) Specially Jawaharlal is earnestly pressing me for it.
('95', 6, 2, 5, 12480) I, however, do not feel that my presence will be of much help, since my line of thinking at the moment is entirely different.
('95', 6, 2, 6, 12606) I have come here because I could not resist Jawahar’s invitation.
('95', 6, 2, 7, 12672) Otherwise my heart is in Bihar.
('95', 6, 2, 8, 12704) It seems I won’t have to stay here for long.
('95', 6, 2, 9, 12749) Maybe, I will have to go to Calcutta.
('95', 6, 2, 10, 12787) Complete peace has not yet been restored there.
('95', 6, 2, 11, 12835) Stray incidents are occurring daily.
('95', 6, 2, 12, 12872) [From Gujarati]
('95', 6, 3, 13, 12888) Biharni Komi Agman, p.
('95', 6, 4, 14, 12911) 7. TALK WITH RAJENDRA PRASAD 1
('95', 6, 5, 15, 12942) BHANGI NIVAS, NEW DELHI, May 2, 1947 I do not wish to stay here for long.
('95', 6, 5, 16, 13016) I hold that if I am able to do something in Bihar or Noakhali, it will have far reaching consequ ences in the whole country.
('95', 6, 5, 17, 13141) Even if we get swaraj, if there is no peace in people’s hearts it will not be of much use.
('95', 6, 5, 18, 13232) And I believe that I can do more work there than here.
('95', 6, 5, 19, 13287) But here I am a prisoner of Jawahar and the Sardar.
('95', 6, 5, 20, 13339) If they release me I would like to leave by the first available train.
('95', 6, 5, 21, 13410) [From Gujarati]

('95', 7, 7, 12, 14087) 10. A LETTER May [2] 2 , 1947 On the train to Delhi I read about Kshitish Babu’s demise.
('95', 7, 7, 13, 14176) I reached Delhi yesterday, and got from Thakkar Bapa your name and address.
('95', 7, 7, 14, 14252) All of us must feel sad about the passing away of an ardent worker like Kshitish Babu.
('95', 7, 7, 15, 14339) But if we all do his work he should not be dead so far as we are concerned.
('95', 7, 7, 16, 14415) Bapa tells me that your sister also is with you.
('95', 7, 7, 17, 14464) I hope you two would render such great service that Kshitish Babu’s name would be immortalized through your lives.

('95', 7, 9, 20, 14615) 11. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 7, 10, 21, 14644) NEW DELHI, May 2, 1947
('95', 7, 11, 22, 14667) After a passage from the Koran was recited, a young man shouted, “Stop it.
('95', 7, 11, 23, 14742) Victory to Hinduism.” Hearing this Gandhiji stopped the prayer and said: Very well, let his wish be granted today.
('95', 7, 12, 24, 14857) Gandhiji asked the man to calm down but he continued to shout.
('95', 7, 12, 25, 14920) 3 Gandhiji said:
('95', 7, 13, 26, 14937) 1 The letter is not available.
('95', 7, 13, 27, 14968) 2 From the reference to Gandhiji’s arrival at Delhi where he reached on May 1. The source, however, has “May 3”.
('95', 7, 13, 28, 15081) 3 In the mean while the police arrived and took the man away.
('95', 8, 0, 1, 15143) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 9
('95', 8, 1, 2, 15182) If my words can reach the policemen I would request them to release the man and allow him to come over here.
('95', 8, 1, 3, 15291) I do not approve of the police coming here to maintain order during the prayer.
('95', 8, 1, 4, 15371) If the police go on arresting people every day and I rely on them to hold the prayer, it would be no prayer at all.
('95', 8, 1, 5, 15487) I can hold the prayer only when all the people gladly allow it to proceed peacefully.
('95', 8, 1, 6, 15573) You saw that I stopped the prayer when the young man wanted it to be stopped.
('95', 8, 1, 7, 15651) I would again stop the prayer if he wants me to do so tomorrow.
('95', 8, 1, 8, 15715) But “Victory to Hinduism” cannot be won in this manner as he has said.
('95', 8, 1, 9, 15786) He must realize that religion only declines by such acts.
('95', 8, 1, 10, 15844) How can we protect our religion by preventing others from praying?
('95', 8, 1, 11, 15911) But I do not blame him.
('95', 8, 1, 12, 15935) Today the atmosphere is such.
('95', 8, 1, 13, 15965) Today everything is seen upside down.
('95', 8, 1, 14, 16003) No one understands the obvious thing.
('95', 8, 1, 15, 16041) Hence, if someone asks me to stop the prayer, I shall submit to the demand.
('95', 8, 1, 16, 16117) But what pains me more is that he created a disturbance in the midst of the prayer.
('95', 8, 1, 17, 16201) I would not have started the prayer at all if he had made his intention known in the beginning.
('95', 8, 1, 18, 16297) Where was the need for the police to intervene?
('95', 8, 1, 19, 16345) It is a matter of shame to me that so much police force should stay here to maintain order during the prayer.
('95', 8, 1, 20, 16455) How can the police protect my religion?
('95', 8, 1, 21, 16495) My religion would be protected only when I myself Protect it.
('95', 8, 1, 22, 16557) Or rather, it is pretentious to say that I would protect my religion.
('95', 8, 1, 23, 16627) It is God who would protect my religion.
('95', 8, 1, 24, 16668) If there is prayer in my heart, God is bound to protect me.
('95', 8, 1, 25, 16728) What does it matter if the external prayer is not conducted ?
('95', 8, 1, 26, 16790) But what can you do?
('95', 8, 1, 27, 16811) You are all sitting quietly.

('95', 25, 6, 7, 52911) May 5, 1947
('95', 25, 7, 8, 52923) DOON CAMPBELL: Is the communal division of India inevitable?
('95', 25, 7, 9, 52984) Will such division solve the communal problem?
('95', 25, 8, 10, 53031) GANDHIJI: Personally, I have always said ‘No’, and I say ‘No’ even now to both these questions.

('95', 29, 1, 2, 60231) 26. A TALK 1
('95', 29, 2, 3, 60244) BHANGI NIVAS, NEW DELHI, May 6, 1947 The only effective means for improving the lot of our people and preventing the eruption of violence around us is our Sudarshan Chakra 2 —the spinning wheel.
('95', 29, 2, 4, 60439) The history of cotton in our country is worth studying.
('95', 29, 2, 5, 60495) Thanks to the British rule—even a sample of the cloth woven by our weavers 150 years ago is not available today.
('95', 29, 2, 6, 60608) As the saying goes the snake has gone leaving only the track behind.
('95', 29, 2, 7, 60677) If everyone in India spins daily, not an inch of cloth need be imported.
('95', 29, 2, 8, 60750) Our Government says that Bengal is poor and so is Orissa.
('95', 29, 2, 9, 60808) But somehow I am not able to swallow this.
('95', 29, 2, 10, 60851) Cotton is not grown anywhere on such a large scale as in our country.
('95', 29, 2, 11, 60921) The truth is we are not poor, we are lazy.
('95', 29, 2, 12, 60964) If we discard laziness and ply the charkha daily for at least half an hour knowing [all its implication], our creative energy will automatically grow.
('95', 29, 2, 13, 61115) I can do without food but not without sacrificial spinning even for a single day.
('95', 29, 2, 14, 61197) Swaraj and peace lie in the spinning wheel.
('95', 29, 2, 15, 61241) When I first took up the spinning wheel I did not have much knowledge about it.
('95', 29, 2, 16, 61321) But my nephew Maganlal Gandhi renounced everything for it and did a lot of research in this field.
('95', 29, 2, 17, 61420) One who possesses the spinning wheel enjoys complete freedom.
('95', 29, 2, 18, 61482) Whereas those depending on mill cloth become slaves of mill owners.
('95', 29, 2, 19, 61550) Every person should determine his own needs and should himself try to fulfil them and seek other’ help only when it becomes unavoidable.
('95', 29, 2, 20, 61687) Unless everyone develops this attitude and becomes completely self reliant, we can never be really free.

('95', 43, 4, 29, 94396) IN THE RAIN TO PATNA May 8, 1947
('95', 43, 5, 30, 94429) DEAR FRIEND, It strikes me that I should summarize what I said and wanted to say and left unfinished for want of time, at our last Sunday’s 1 meeting.
('95', 43, 6, 31, 94580) 1 May 4; vide “Interview with Lord Mountbatten”, 4 5 1947
('95', 44, 0, 1, 94638) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 45
('95', 44, 1, 2, 94678) I Whatever may be said to the contrary, it would be a blunder of the first magnitude for the British to be a party in any way whatsoever to the division of India.
('95', 44, 1, 3, 94841) If it has to come, let it come after the British withdrawal, as a result of understanding between the parties or of an armed conflict which according to Quaid e Azam Jinnah is taboo.
('95', 44, 1, 4, 95024) Protection of minorities can be guaranteed by establishing a court of arbitration in the event of difference of opinion among contending parties.
('95', 44, 1, 5, 95170) 2. Meantime the Interim Government should be composed either of Congressmen or those whose names the Congress chooses or of Muslim League men or those whom the League chooses.
('95', 44, 1, 6, 95346) The dual control of today, lacking team work and team spirit, is harmful for the country.
('95', 44, 1, 7, 95436) The parties exhaust themselves in the effort to retain their seat and to placate you.
('95', 44, 1, 8, 95522) Want of team spirit demoralizes the Govern ment and imperils the integrity of the services so essential for good and efficient government.
('95', 44, 1, 9, 95661) 3. Referendum at this stage in the Frontier (or any Province for that matter) is a dangerous thing in itself.
('95', 44, 1, 10, 95771) You have to deal with the material that faces you.
('95', 44, 1, 11, 95822) In any case nothing should or can be done over Dr. Khan Saheb’s head as Premier.
('95', 44, 1, 12, 95903) Note that this paragraph is relevant only if division is at all to be countenanced.
('95', 44, 1, 13, 95987) 4. I feel sure that partition of the Punjab and Bengal is wrong in every case and a needless irritant for the League.
('95', 44, 1, 14, 96105) This as well as all innovation can come after the British withdrawal, not before, except always for mutual agreement.
('95', 44, 1, 15, 96223) Whilst the British power is functioning in India, it must be held principally responsible for the preservation of peace in the country.
('95', 44, 1, 16, 96359) That machine seems to be cracking under the existing strain which is caused by the raising of various hopes that cannot or must not be fulfilled.
('95', 44, 1, 17, 96505) These have no place during the remaining thirteen months.
('95', 44, 1, 18, 96563) This period can be most profitably shortened if the minds of all were focussed on the sole task of withdrawal.
('95', 44, 1, 19, 96674) You and you alone can do it to the exclusion of all other activity so far as the British occupation is concerned.
('95', 44, 1, 20, 96788) 5. Your task as undisputed master of naval warfare, great as it was, was nothing compared to what you are called to do now.
('95', 44, 1, 21, 96912) The single mindedness and clarity that gave you success are much more required in this work.
('95', 44, 1, 22, 97005) 6. If you are not to leave a legacy of chaos behind, you have to
('95', 45, 0, 1, 97070) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 45, 1, 2, 97111) make your choice and leave the Government of the whole of India including the States to one party.
('95', 45, 1, 3, 97210) The Constituent Assembly has to provide for the governance even of that part of India which is not represented by the Muslim League or some States.
('95', 45, 1, 4, 97358) 7. Non partition of the Punjab and Bengal does not mean that the minorities in these Provinces are to be neglected.
('95', 45, 1, 5, 97474) In both the Provinces they are large and powerful enough to arrest and demand attention.
('95', 45, 1, 6, 97563) If the popular Governments cannot placate them, the Governors should during the interregnum actively interfere.
('95', 45, 1, 7, 97675) 8. The intransmissibility of paramountcy is a vicious doctrine, if it means that they 1 can become sovereign and a menace for indepen dent India.
('95', 45, 1, 8, 97821) All the power wherever exercised by the British in India must automatically descend to the successor.
('95', 45, 1, 9, 97923) Thus the people of the States become as much part of independent India as the people of British India.
('95', 45, 1, 10, 98026) The present Princes are puppets created or tolerated for the upkeep and prestige of the British Power.
('95', 45, 1, 11, 98129) The unchecked powers exercised by them over their people is probably the worst blot on the British Crown.
('95', 45, 1, 12, 98235) The Princes under the new regime can exercise only such powers as trustees can and as can be given to them by the Constituent Assembly.
('95', 45, 1, 13, 98371) It follows that they cannot maintain private armies or arms factories.
('95', 45, 1, 14, 98442) Such ability and statecraft as they possess must be at the disposal of the Republic and must be used for the good of their people and the people as a whole.
('95', 45, 1, 15, 98599) I have merely stated what should be done with the States.
('95', 45, 1, 16, 98657) It is not for me to show in this letter how this can be done.
('95', 45, 1, 17, 98719) 9. Similarly difficult but not so baffling is the question of the Civil Service.
('95', 45, 1, 18, 98800) Its members should be taught from now to accommodate themselves to the new regime.
('95', 45, 1, 19, 98883) They may not be partisans taking sides.
('95', 45, 1, 20, 98923) The slightest trace of communalism among them should be severely dealt with.
('95', 45, 1, 21, 99000) The English element in it should know that they owe loyalty to the new regime rather than to the old and therefore to Great Britain.
('95', 45, 1, 22, 99133) The habit of regarding themselves as rulers and therefore superiors must give place to the spirit of true service of the people.
('95', 45, 1, 23, 99262) II 10. I had a very pleasant two hours and three quarters with Quaid e Azam Jinnah on Tuesday last.

('95', 47, 2, 3, 100712) PATNA, May 8, 1947 I do not find fault with you for coming to ask me.
('95', 47, 2, 4, 100782) 1 You have been trained that way.
('95', 47, 2, 5, 100816) Will you go to every compartment and ask the occupants as you ask me?

('95', 47, 2, 9, 101065) They have come as family members.
('95', 47, 2, 10, 101099) If they had not come I would not have been able to do anything to them.
('95', 47, 2, 11, 101171) But at heart we are old colleagues.
('95', 47, 2, 12, 101207) They have come to me like many others who would have come to meet their relatives passing through the station.
('95', 47, 2, 13, 101318) It is your duty to blow the whistle and start the train at the correct time, even if the highest official may be in the train.
('95', 47, 2, 14, 101445) It is another thing if your superiors have given you any instructions in writing.
('95', 47, 2, 15, 101527) Except in such a case you must carry on your routine work.
('95', 47, 2, 16, 101586) It would be good training for you and also for these Ministers as well as the people.
('95', 47, 2, 17, 101672) You should not be scared at the sight of the Ministers.
('95', 47, 2, 18, 101728) They are servants of the people.
('95', 47, 2, 19, 101761) Hence you should in fact be fearless in their presence.
('95', 47, 2, 20, 101817) The Ministers too should regard persons in their departments not as servants but as their younger brothers.
('95', 47, 2, 21, 101925) Then alone would we be happy and be able to enjoy the fruits of democracy.
('95', 47, 2, 22, 102000) So the rule which applies to other passengers in this train also applies to me.
('95', 47, 2, 23, 102080) Of course I must admit that the rule is not observed fully.
('95', 47, 2, 24, 102140) For instance, even though we travel third, this compartment is reserved for the two or three of us.
('95', 47, 2, 25, 102240) But I can do nothing about it.
('95', 47, 2, 26, 102271) If this is not done, everybody would want to get into this compartment.
('95', 47, 2, 27, 102343) So, this practice of obliging me by reserving my compartment has been continued since the days of the British.
('95', 47, 2, 28, 102454) I am not saying this to scold you.
('95', 47, 2, 29, 102489) Please do not feel hurt.
('95', 47, 2, 30, 102514) But this is an occasion from which all of us can learn something, and how would you know if I do not mention it to you?
('95', 47, 2, 31, 102634) And I am a teacher after all, and it is my nature that I cannot help correcting what my conscience regards as an error.
('95', 47, 2, 32, 102754) Well, I have given you these few minutes and now do not hesitate to start the train at your convenience.
('95', 47, 2, 33, 102859) I know you have come to me to show me courtesy,
('95', 47, 3, 34, 102907) 1 As Gandhiji was busy talking to the Bihar Ministers the Station Master came to enquire whether he could start the train.

('95', 52, 1, 2, 111907) 38. INTERVIEW TO ABUL HASHEM 1
('95', 52, 2, 3, 111938) SODEPUR, Saturday, May 10, 1947
('95', 52, 3, 4, 111970) Hashem Saheb opened his case 2 by stating that Bengalis were after all Bengalis, whether Hindu or Muslim.
('95', 52, 3, 5, 112076) They had a common language, a common culture and did not wish to be ruled by Pakistanis who lived a thousand miles away.
('95', 52, 3, 6, 112197) Gandhiji said : But haven’t we been so long ruled by people who live seven thousand miles away?
('95', 52, 4, 7, 112293) Yes, but then that would mean that Pakistanis of the West would rule over us in Bengal.
('95', 52, 4, 8, 112381) But supposing they do not rule over you, and you wish to form a voluntary alliance with Pakistan because you have a common religion which both of you wish to propagate throughout the world, then where is the objection?
('95', 52, 5, 9, 112600) But then you are talking of Pan Islamism.
('95', 52, 5, 10, 112642) Yes I am.
('95', 52, 5, 11, 112652) Perhaps you do not know how deep the Muslim feeling about it is.
('95', 52, 5, 12, 112717) I had evidence of that even while I was a student in England many years ago.
('95', 52, 5, 13, 112794) What is then your objection to a voluntary federation of different countries professing the same religion?
('95', 52, 6, 14, 112901) Hashem Saheb did not reply.
('95', 52, 6, 15, 112929) Then Gandhiji asked me 3 to bring a Bengali primer which he had been reading lately.
('95', 52, 6, 16, 113014) When this was brought, Gandhiji proceeded to tell Hashem Saheb that, to all intents and purposes, he was trying to become a Bengali.
('95', 52, 6, 17, 113147) He found hardly any difference between the language of a Bengali Hindu and a Bengali Muslim.
('95', 52, 6, 18, 113240) Bengal was the only province in India where common Muslims did not understand Urdu.

('95', 55, 3, 13, 119762) 40. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 55, 4, 14, 119791) SODEPUR, May 10, 1947
('95', 55, 5, 15, 119813) Speaking at the prayer gathering Mahatma Gandhi addressed himself to two questions that were asked of him.
('95', 55, 5, 16, 119920) In view of the sourness between Hindus and Muslims that seemed to be daily growing, was it possible for the two to become friends?
('95', 55, 5, 17, 120051) He answered emphatically that the enmity could not last for ever.
('95', 55, 5, 18, 120117) They were brothers and must remain so in spite of temporary insanity.
('95', 55, 5, 19, 120187) But perpetual feud was not an impossibility between communities as it was not between two individuals.
('95', 55, 5, 20, 120290) He hoped that that would not happen, for he prophesied that in that case they would bury the two religions in India and would sell their freedom for a mess of pottage.
('95', 55, 6, 21, 120458) The second question was, could partition of Bengal be avoided in view of the rising Hindu opinion in its favour.
('95', 55, 6, 22, 120571) Gandhiji recognized the force of that opinion.
('95', 55, 6, 23, 120618) He was not in a position to pronounce an opinion.
('95', 55, 6, 24, 120668) But he could say without fear of contradiction that if there was partition, the Muslims majority would be responsible for it, and what was more, the Muslim Government that was in power.
('95', 55, 6, 25, 120854) If he were the Chief Minister of Bengal, he would plead with his Hindu brethren to forget the past.
('95', 55, 6, 26, 120954) He would say to them that he was as much a Bengali as they were.
('95', 55, 6, 27, 121019) Differences in religion could not part the two.
('95', 55, 6, 28, 121067) He and they spoke the same language, had inherited the same culture.
('95', 55, 6, 29, 121136) All that was Bengal’s was common to both, of which both could be equally proud.
('95', 55, 6, 30, 121216) Bengal was Bengal.
('95', 55, 6, 31, 121235) It was neither the Punjab nor Bombay nor anything else.
('95', 55, 7, 32, 121291) If the Chief Minister could possibly take up that attitude, he (the speaker)
('95', 56, 0, 1, 121368) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 57
('95', 56, 1, 2, 121408) would undertake to go with him from place to place and reason with Hindu audiences and he made bold to say that there would not be a Hindu opponent left of the unity of Bengal, the unity for which Hindus and Mussalmans had fought together so valiantly and undone “the settled fact” 1 of so powerful a Viceroy as Lord Curzon.
('95', 56, 1, 3, 121733) If he were Suhrawardy he would invite the Hindus to partition his body before they thought of partitioning Bengal.
('95', 56, 1, 4, 121848) If he had that sturdy love for Bengal and Bengalis, whether Hindus or Mussalmans, that love would melt the stoniest Hindu heart.
('95', 56, 1, 5, 121977) As it was, fear and suspicion had seized the Hindu mind.
('95', 56, 2, 6, 122034) He could not forget Noakhali or even Calcutta, if all he heard was true, as it was equally true of the Muslim mind in Bihar and he had not hesitated to tell the Hindus of Bihar that they should remove all suspicion and fear from the Muslims mind.
('95', 56, 2, 7, 122281) He believed in the sovereign rule of the law of love which made no distinction of race, colour, caste or creed.
('95', 56, 2, 8, 122393) He was glad that he had in Quaid e Azam Jinnah a powerful partner in the belief, which was no secret from the world.

('95', 60, 3, 27, 131182) If not now, in the coming year or two mill owners and workers will have to develop relations like father and sons.

('95', 60, 3, 29, 131328) If this does not happen both will come to grief.

('95', 61, 3, 9, 131925) 48. INTERVIEW TO H. S. SUHRAWARDY 1
('95', 61, 4, 10, 131961) SODEPUR, Sunday, May 11, 1947
('95', 61, 5, 11, 131991) H. S. Suhrawardy, the chief sponsor of the united sovereign Bengal scheme, drew a rosy picture of the proposal.
('95', 61, 5, 12, 132103) Gandhiji said that a new Bengal could not be born in utter disregard of the past.
('95', 61, 5, 13, 132185) When the past was so full of wrongs, how could people believe in the sincerity of the new proposal unless past wrongs were set right?
('95', 61, 5, 14, 132319) Suhrawardy said, his Government had been wholly impartial and equal justice had been meted out to all; otherwise how could it have the support of a large number of Hindus?
('95', 61, 5, 15, 132491) Gandhiji expressed the opinion that this was no different from the argument of British imperialists.
('95', 61, 6, 16, 132592) A friend of mine 2 had written a letter in which he described the utter incompetence of the Government and the veiled connivance of police officers in encouraging Muslim rioters.
('95', 61, 6, 17, 132771) Gandhiji had read his letter and asked me how to hand it over to the Chief Minister.
('95', 61, 6, 18, 132856) The latter went through it and said, “Yes, it is a bad case.
('95', 61, 6, 19, 132917) But I am sure, you realize that this is an exception.”
('95', 61, 7, 20, 132972) Then with Gandhiji’s permission, I placed before Suhrawardy another case of murder 3 in which the police had not taken up any enquiry even when seven days had passed.
('95', 61, 7, 21, 133139) Suhrawardy tried to bypass the charge against his Government by saying, “Do you know, there are more than half a dozen versions of that event?
('95', 61, 7, 22, 133282) One even accuses me of complicity in the murder.” Gandhiji had been silently listening to our conversation.
('95', 61, 7, 23, 133390) He now broke in by saying: Yes, you are responsible not only for that murder but for every life lost in Bengal, whether Hindu or Muslim.
('95', 61, 8, 24, 133527) 1 Who was accompanied by Mohammad Ali and Abdul Hashem.

('95', 62, 1, 2, 133793) Suhrawardy immediately retorted, “No, it is you who are responsible for it, for you have denied justice to the Mussalmans.”
('95', 62, 2, 3, 133917) I have rarely seen Gandhiji lose his temper in public.
('95', 62, 2, 4, 133972) For one moment he flared up and said: Don’t talk rot !
('95', 62, 3, 5, 134027) But immediately he became restrained and calmed down.
('95', 62, 3, 6, 134081) He told Shaheed [Suhrawardy] that if he was really serious about his new Bengal, he should go amongst the hooligans, wherever there was disturbance, and stop the mischief by risking his own life if necessary.
('95', 62, 3, 7, 134290) If you do it even for a day, it will transform the atmosphere— not only in Calcutta but in the whole of India.

('95', 62, 6, 11, 134511) SODEPUR, May 11, 1947
('95', 62, 7, 12, 134533) Mahatma Gandhi said that he had the privilege of receiving Shaheed Sahib at Sodepur.
('95', 62, 7, 13, 134618) He had wished to go to the latter’s house but he would not let him go to his place.
('95', 62, 7, 14, 134702) He had no information to give on the interview save that he had to repeat what he had said yesterday.
('95', 62, 8, 15, 134804) Gandhiji then addressed himself to the two questions put to him at the prayer meeting.
('95', 62, 8, 16, 134891) The first was: “You have advised us to work for an undivided Bengal.
('95', 62, 8, 17, 134960) But can there be an undivided Bengal with a divided India?
('95', 62, 8, 18, 135019) What can we do to preserve a united Bengal in a united India?
('95', 62, 9, 19, 135081) The answer was that if what he had said was well understood it followed that nothing could happen without the joint wish of both Hindus and Muslims.
('95', 62, 9, 20, 135230) If a third party was not to decide their fate it would only be decided by their joint will.
('95', 62, 9, 21, 135322) Then there was no question as yet of a divided India.
('95', 62, 9, 22, 135376) If the distant event unfortunately did come to pass, the joint and free will of Hindu and Muslim Bengalis would decide which of these divisions to join.
('95', 62, 10, 23, 135529) 1 Later Gandhiji remarked: “What a curious man !

('95', 62, 10, 25, 135618) He wants people to trust him because, he says, the new Bengal which he wants to build will assure to all communities equal treatment.
('95', 62, 10, 26, 135752) But the future is the child of the present.
('95', 62, 10, 27, 135796) If what is happening in Calcutta today is an earnest of things to come, it does not bode well for his plan.” 2 There was a mammoth gathering, representing all communities.
('95', 62, 10, 28, 135968) Many had to turn away for want of space.

('95', 63, 1, 2, 136050) The second question was: “The British have not quit.

('95', 63, 4, 7, 136467) 50. NOTE TO MANU GANDHI
('95', 63, 5, 8, 136491) May 12, 1947 The more you rest, the sooner you will recover.
('95', 63, 5, 9, 136552) Try to enshrine Ramanama in your heart.
('95', 63, 5, 10, 136592) In this way you will not be omitting any of the jobs you do for me.
('95', 63, 5, 11, 136660) Understand that when you rest yourself that too is a part of my work.
('95', 63, 5, 12, 136730) Since you have dedicated yourself wholly to me you must lie down as long as I ask you to.
('95', 63, 5, 13, 136820) Instead you go on working and I have to explain to you the meaning of the Gita.
('95', 63, 5, 14, 136900) At the prayers you daily recite the verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad but you do not act upon it.
('95', 63, 5, 15, 136999) How can your body stand it if you go on preparing khakhras 1 and do the other odd jobs for me?
('95', 63, 5, 16, 137094) The body does not belong to you; it belongs to God.
('95', 63, 5, 17, 137146) Even if we live in rented quarters we have to keep them clean in our own interest.
('95', 63, 5, 18, 137229) The same thing applies to the body.
('95', 63, 5, 19, 137265) Hence ruining one’s health by overworking amounts to an offence against God.

('95', 66, 1, 2, 140668) 54. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('95', 66, 2, 3, 140699) SODEPUR, May 12, 1947 The thought that is uppermost in my mind today is how to combat the goonda rule that seems to be fast enveloping us.
('95', 66, 2, 4, 140838) This I say of all India, perhaps it is true more or less of the whole world.
('95', 66, 2, 5, 140915) Let the Hindus not deceive themselves with the belief that it is well with the Hindus.
('95', 66, 2, 6, 141002) As a devout Hindu that I claim to be, I wish to affirm that we Hindus will be living in a fool’s paradise if we harboured any such thought.
('95', 66, 2, 7, 141142) Goondaism is no preparation for taking the place of foreign rule.
('95', 66, 2, 8, 141208) The thoughtless interference at prayer meetings is not a small symptom of the disease I am describing.
('95', 66, 2, 9, 141311) Intolerance is a form of goondaism.
('95', 66, 2, 10, 141347) It is no less disgraceful than the savagery which we see announced in the daily Press.
('95', 66, 2, 11, 141434) Let all political workers, be they Hindus, Muslims or any other, ponder well over what is happening before their eyes.
('95', 66, 2, 12, 141553) Let it not be said by the future generation that we were trying to learn how to lose the liberty before it was even gained.
('95', 66, 2, 13, 141677) I would ask all the schoolmasters of India, now that they are no longer under the observation of the foreign masters, to recognize their true function even at the risk of their lives and give the right bent to the minds of those whom it is their proud privilege to mould.
('95', 66, 2, 14, 141949) Amrita Bazar Patrika, 13 5 1947

('95', 70, 5, 14, 149726) 59. TALK WITH MANU GANDHI
('95', 70, 6, 15, 149752) May 13, 1947 Look, I am now fresh after ten minutes of rest.
('95', 70, 6, 16, 149813) So long as God grants me this capacity to take a short nap, everything is well.

('95', 72, 3, 15, 154152) 61. INTERVIEW TO SHYAMAPRASAD MOOKERJEE
('95', 72, 4, 16, 154192) SODEPUR, Tuesday, May 13, 1947
('95', 72, 5, 17, 154223) Shyamaprasad 1 had heard that the scheme for united sovereign Bengal had received Gandhiji’s blessings.
('95', 72, 5, 18, 154327) So he had come to ascertain the truth of the report.
('95', 72, 5, 19, 154380) Gandhiji replied that he had not yet made up his mind about it but was trying to find out what the proposal really meant.
('95', 72, 5, 20, 154502) Then he asked Shyamaprasad for his own opinion on the scheme.
('95', 72, 6, 21, 154564) Shyamaprasad began by saying that although Mr. Suhrawardy was apparently its author, it was really being sponsored by the British commercial interests in Bengal.
('95', 72, 6, 22, 154726) If Bengal were partitioned, it would create serious difficulties for the jute industry, for the mills would be in West Bengal and the raw materials in another State.
('95', 72, 6, 23, 154892) Moreover, he said that the Viceroy, Lord Mountbatten, had personally asked him to give the proposal careful consideration.
('95', 72, 6, 24, 155015) Gandhiji said: So your objection is on account of its parentage !
('95', 72, 6, 25, 155081) No, I want you to criticize the scheme on its merits.
('95', 72, 7, 26, 155135) Then Shyamaprasad proceeded to say that although Mr. Suhrawardy was now sponsoring the cause of a united Bengal, yet, once division had taken place, what was there to prevent this Bengal from seeking voluntary alliance with Pakistan?
('95', 72, 7, 27, 155369) He could
('95', 72, 8, 28, 155378) 1 President of the Bengal Provincial Hindu Mahasabha
('95', 73, 0, 1, 155431) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 73, 1, 2, 155472) surely manipulate a decision of this kind by means of the majority of Muslim votes.
('95', 73, 1, 3, 155556) Gandhiji said: But has he not spoken of “mutual consent”, between Hindus and Muslims in the formation of a separate Bengal?
('95', 73, 2, 4, 155680) Shyamaprasad asked what difference that made so long as the majority of the Legislative Assembly were Muslims.
('95', 73, 2, 5, 155791) Gandhiji replied: But a decision by a simple numerical majority is not by “mutual consent”.
('95', 73, 2, 6, 155883) I would interpret that term differently.
('95', 73, 2, 7, 155924) It ought to mean that if a majority of Hindu members and a majority of Muslim members agree to form a separate sovereign State, then it comes into being by “mutual consent”, not otherwise.
('95', 73, 2, 8, 156113) That majority may be 51 is to 49 or may be fixed at any other figure by mutual discussion before the agreement is entered into.
('95', 73, 2, 9, 156241) And if Suhrawardy has to win the majority of the Hindu members of the Assembly over to his side, don’t you see that the present communal situation in Bengal will immediately change for the better?
('95', 73, 3, 10, 156438) But supposing Suhrawardy does succeed in winning over many Hindu members and a separate state is formed, then, one day, that state may federate itself with Pakistan if the decision is by majority of votes.

('95', 73, 4, 12, 156740) Shyamaprasad then asked what would happen if the majority of Hindu members wanted to federate with India and the majority of Muslim members with Pakistan.

('95', 73, 5, 16, 157119) But can you contemplate Bengal lying separated from the rest of India?

('95', 73, 6, 18, 157217) Finally, Gandhiji said to Shyamaprasad that we should take Mr. Suhrawardy’s new proposal at its face value, even if we may have no faith in him personally.
('95', 73, 6, 19, 157373) Preservation of united Bengal in a united India should not be made the condition precedent in the present negotiation, that would defeat one’s purpose.

('95', 73, 6, 21, 157658) An admission that Bengali Hindus and Bengali Mussalmans were one would really be a severe blow against the two nation theory of the League.
('95', 73, 6, 22, 157798) If therefore Mr. Suhrawardy was prepared to accept the real meaning of the term “mutual consent”, it would mean either the end of the League or of Mr. Suhrawardy.

('95', 74, 1, 2, 158026) 62. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 74, 2, 3, 158055) SODEPUR, May 13, 1947
('95', 74, 3, 4, 158077) At today’s prayer meeting Gandhiji dealt with the questions that were put before him.
('95', 74, 4, 5, 158163) The first was: What could we do to save ourselves and our culture—whether Hindu or Muslim?
('95', 74, 5, 6, 158254) Gandhiji said that he thought that nobody else could protect their culture for them.
('95', 74, 5, 7, 158339) They had to protect it themselves and could destroy it by their folly.
('95', 74, 5, 8, 158410) Thus, if Bengal had one culture, as he believed it had, it was for the people of Bengal to protect it.
('95', 74, 6, 9, 158513) The second question was: When everything at the top goes wrong, can the goodness of the people at the bottom assert itself against its mischievous influence?
('95', 74, 7, 10, 158671) In answer, Gandhiji said that if the people at the top went wrong, it was certainly open to, and it was the duty of those at the bottom, to remove the wrong top even as he would remove an umbrella which appeared to be at the top but which was sustained by him.
('95', 74, 8, 11, 158932) Thus Pandit Nehru was at the top.
('95', 74, 8, 12, 158966) But in reality he was sustained by them.
('95', 74, 8, 13, 159007) If he went wrong, those at the bottom could remove him without trouble.
('95', 74, 8, 14, 159079) Coming nearer home if they found Suhrawardy Saheb to be unworthy, they at the bottom could certainly remove him, not by physical force but by the way he [ Gandhiji ] had had the honour of putting before them.
('95', 74, 8, 15, 159288) The argument that he was elected by the Muslim voters was beside the point.
('95', 74, 9, 16, 159364) It all boiled down to the fact that if the people at the bottom were ignorant, they would be exploited.
('95', 74, 9, 17, 159468) Such was the case with the English.
('95', 74, 9, 18, 159504) When the people realized their strength and the fact that the bottom sustained the top, it would be well with them.
('95', 74, 9, 19, 159620) Therefore, he would say that if the top was wrong there was something radically wrong with the bottom.
('95', 74, 9, 20, 159723) Let them, therefore, dispel their ignorant helplessness.
('95', 74, 10, 21, 159780) Before he dealt with the question, Gandhiji told some demonstrators that they need not be afraid of his doing anything that they did not like.
('95', 74, 10, 22, 159923) He represented nobody but himself.
('95', 74, 10, 23, 159958) He could only give advice which they were free to accept or reject.
('95', 74, 10, 24, 160026) Therefore, if Bengal was divided or united, it would be their act.
('95', 74, 10, 25, 160093) Harijan, 25 5 1947

('95', 81, 5, 17, 172547) 72. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 81, 6, 18, 172576) PATNA, May 15, 1947
('95', 81, 7, 19, 172596) Gandhiji addressed the prayer gathering today in Bankipore Maidan at Patna after a fortnight.
('95', 81, 7, 20, 172690) In the interval, he said, he had been to Delhi and Calcutta.
('95', 81, 7, 21, 172751) He had not foreseen his visit to Calcutta.
('95', 81, 7, 22, 172794) For, his vow of do or die was taken only for Noakhali and Bihar.
('95', 81, 7, 23, 172859) But what he heard about Calcutta made him feel that he might be of some use there.
('95', 81, 7, 24, 172942) And he could say that he had not been entirely unsuccessful.
('95', 81, 7, 25, 173003) In Calcutta also he was serving Bihar.
('95', 81, 7, 26, 173042) For the cause was the same.
('95', 81, 7, 27, 173070) By going to Calcutta or elsewhere, where he might be called upon to go in future, though the possibility was very remote, he did not leave out Bihar or Noakhali.
('95', 81, 7, 28, 173232) It only extended the field of the operation of his do or die mission.
('95', 81, 7, 29, 173302) He felt that success at one place would be followed by success at other places.
('95', 81, 7, 30, 173382) The future was, however, in God’s hands.
('95', 81, 8, 31, 173423) During his absence Gandhiji had kept himself informed about the work going
('95', 82, 0, 1, 173498) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 83
('95', 82, 1, 2, 173538) on in Bihar.
('95', 82, 1, 3, 173551) During the day he had received more information.
('95', 82, 1, 4, 173600) Affairs in Bihar moved slowly.
('95', 82, 1, 5, 173631) The Biharis were, however, not slow when they committed acts of madness.
('95', 82, 1, 6, 173704) There was no reason why they should be slow in making amends.
('95', 82, 1, 7, 173766) The rains were coming.
('95', 82, 1, 8, 173789) They were working against time.
('95', 82, 1, 9, 173821) The Ministry had concentrated the control of rehabilitation work in Ansari Saheb’s hands for the sake of efficiency.
('95', 82, 1, 10, 173938) General Shah Nawaz, who had gone on a short leave, would be presently in their midst.
('95', 82, 1, 11, 174024) If sufficient capable women workers imbued with the spirit of loving service came forward to work among the Muslim women, he felt sure the work would go forward.
('95', 82, 2, 12, 174186) Gandhiji was sure that if Bihar succeeded in instilling confidence in the Muslims, her influence would be felt throughout India.
('95', 82, 2, 13, 174315) Some Hindus wrote to Gandhiji to ask if he expected them to flatter and fawn on the Mussalmans.
('95', 82, 2, 14, 174411) He, as a life long fighter, with truth and ahimsa as his weapons, could not countenance that.
('95', 82, 2, 15, 174505) What he counselled was the control of their baser instincts of anger and hatred.
('95', 82, 2, 16, 174586) And if avoiding harshness and adopting perfect gentlemanliness was flattery, he would not hesitate to use that word.
('95', 82, 2, 17, 174703) Gandhiji then informed the congregation that he could not bear the strain of touring every place in the heat.
('95', 82, 2, 18, 174813) He had to content himself with holding his prayer meeting at different places every day.

('95', 84, 3, 6, 177258) I was by her side.
('95', 84, 3, 7, 177277) It is a little before six in the morning just now.

('95', 84, 3, 9, 177385) I had suspected even in Delhi that it was appendicitis.

('95', 84, 3, 12, 177548) I, therefore, called in the doctors yesterday.

('95', 84, 3, 16, 177765) Whom can I advise now, ‘Die but do not give up nature cure.’ I will be satisfied if I can put that into practice in my own life.
('95', 84, 3, 17, 177894) You must not worry.
('95', 84, 3, 18, 177914) Madalasa and Santok visited Manu at twelve.
('95', 84, 3, 19, 177958) She is fine.

('95', 88, 3, 9, 184144) 82. LETTER TO A PHYSICIAN
('95', 88, 4, 10, 184170) May 16, 1947 I had read your letter as soon I received it.
('95', 88, 4, 11, 184229) But I saw the accompanying article only today.
('95', 88, 4, 12, 184276) I was happy to read it.
('95', 88, 4, 13, 184300) It is not enough to say that you have cured all your patients through yoga exercises.
('95', 88, 4, 14, 184386) You ought to have indicated the particular exercises and mentioned whether diet, etc., played an important part.
('95', 88, 4, 15, 184499) In all books whether worthwhile or no, details are mentioned.
('95', 88, 4, 16, 184561) You should do the same.
('95', 88, 4, 17, 184585) I thought of you when out of sheer despair I had to seek the help of doctors for my own little girl.
('95', 88, 4, 18, 184686) I told myself how nice it would have been if I could have cured this girl with the help of yoga exercises, etc.
('95', 88, 4, 19, 184798) She had appendicitis and inflammation.
('95', 88, 4, 20, 184837) She could not be cured with the earth water and diet [treatment].
('95', 88, 4, 21, 184903) I consulted two naturopaths.
('95', 88, 4, 22, 184932) They also could not help.
('95', 88, 4, 23, 184958) A hakim even suggested treating her with myrobalan and wood apple.

('95', 89, 3, 4, 185569) Gandhiji referred to his visit to the refugee camp 1 nearby prior to the prayer
('95', 89, 4, 5, 185649) meeting.
('95', 89, 4, 6, 185658) He had not been able to see it as thoroughly as he would have liked to do.

('95', 89, 6, 8, 185805) The camp was being run on the principle of self help.
('95', 89, 6, 9, 185859) Men worked and were paid their due.
('95', 89, 6, 10, 185895) The children also worked, though they were paid more than what they would be otherwise entitled to.
('95', 89, 6, 11, 185995) Such self help bred self respect.
('95', 89, 7, 12, 186029) They were innocent men and women, who had suffered at the hands of the
('95', 89, 8, 13, 186100) Hindus who had gone temporarily insane.
('95', 89, 8, 14, 186140) It was their duty, therefore, to make all the
('95', 89, 9, 15, 186186) amends they could.

('95', 89, 14, 21, 186537) fear or due to false propaganda, to come back.

('95', 100, 7, 10, 204892) 100. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 100, 10, 11, 204922) May 18, 1947
('95', 100, 11, 12, 204935) It pained me that yesterday though men and women had
('95', 100, 12, 13, 204988) assembled in large numbers my voice could not reach them all owing to the clumsiness, or inefficiency, of the volunteers, or because of some defect in the loud speakers.2 As a result people failed to maintain silence.
('95', 100, 12, 14, 205206) It is a matter of shame for us.
('95', 100, 12, 15, 205238) We ought to learn how to maintain perfect silence even when we gather in hundreds of thousands.
('95', 100, 12, 16, 205334) If we fail to learn this, we shall not be able to protect our independence.
('95', 100, 12, 17, 205410) Democracy requires everyone, man or woman, to realize his or her responsibility.
('95', 100, 12, 18, 205491) This is what is meant by panchayat raj.
('95', 100, 12, 19, 205531) A single limb of the body ceasing to function properly throws the whole body mechanism out of gear.
('95', 100, 12, 20, 205631) Similarly, the whole of India is one body and we are its limbs.
('95', 100, 12, 21, 205695) If we become lax, the whole country would be affected likewise.
('95', 100, 12, 22, 205759) That is why I lay so much stress on the need for discipline at meetings, on trains or on railway platforms.
('95', 100, 12, 23, 205867) It is on such occasions that we are tested.
('95', 100, 12, 24, 205911) I go so far as to say that if we had learnt to keep order at gatherings of hundreds of thousands, riots like those in Bihar would not have occurred.
('95', 100, 12, 25, 206060) Today, the smallest disturbance is given a communal colour, with the result that it provides an opportunity for a communal flare up.
('95', 100, 12, 26, 206193) Volunteers, therefore, should understand this and educate the people to keep order at

('95', 113, 5, 11, 228687) HILSA, May 20, 1947 On my way I have heard all about Hilsa.Here the Hindu brethren have played havoc.
('95', 113, 5, 12, 228789) It is a matter of regret and shame for us, not of joy.
('95', 113, 5, 13, 228844) The greatest sinner becomes the greatest saint provided he makes genuine atonement for his sins.
('95', 113, 5, 14, 228941) Hinduism, Islam and Christi anity are full of such instances where great sinners turned great saints through sincere atonement and pious deeds.
('95', 113, 5, 15, 229085) What is the remedy for the happenings in Bihar?
('95', 113, 5, 16, 229133) I am wondering how best to act or speak to you so that it might change your hearts.
('95', 113, 5, 17, 229217) Committing a wrong is as bad as being in hell.
('95', 113, 5, 18, 229264) But then no one remains at peace in hell.
('95', 113, 5, 19, 229306) One would like to run away from there as soon as possible.
('95', 113, 5, 20, 229365) In fact, comm itting anevil act is even worse than being in hell.
('95', 113, 5, 21, 229431) If this is the reaction on the body, what about the spirit?
('95', 113, 5, 22, 229491) It would prove beneficial for the Hindus, for India and the world if we atoned for the evil deeds committed here.
('95', 113, 5, 23, 229605) How can we atone for it?
('95', 113, 5, 24, 229630) It has been suggested to me that I should stay and work among those who had resorted to violence and should go from house to house; it might perhaps change their hearts.
('95', 113, 5, 25, 229800) But owing to the hot weather I am not able to follow this advice.
('95', 113, 5, 26, 229866) No doubt the heat of agony and shame is more unbearable than that which affects the body, however severe it might be.
('95', 113, 5, 27, 229984) But man cannot get over his love of life.
('95', 113, 5, 28, 230026) He is afraid to work in this heat lest he should fall ill.
('95', 113, 5, 29, 230085) It might be called lack of faith.
('95', 113, 5, 30, 230119) But if my own faith is not firm enough what can I say to others?
('95', 113, 5, 31, 230184) I quietly bear with whatever is said about me.
('95', 113, 5, 32, 230231) With whatever strength and gift of speech that God has granted me, I try to speak to you to the best of my ability.
('95', 113, 5, 33, 230347) I observe that the Muslim brethren who return to their villages
('95', 114, 0, 1, 230411) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 115
('95', 114, 1, 2, 230452) go back again because their houses which had been destroyed or burnt down are yet to be rebuilt.The rains are approaching.
('95', 114, 1, 3, 230575) When shall we rebuild those houses and persuade the Muslims to return?

('95', 115, 6, 13, 233243) If Kosambi leaves the final decision in this regard to us, I would advise cremation as the best form of disposal.
('95', 115, 6, 14, 233357) It is now being recognized as such throughout the world.

('95', 118, 2, 13, 238802) As Tulsidas says, “The name of Rama has become greater than Rama Himself”; similarly the name of the Congress has become greater than the Congress.
('95', 118, 2, 14, 238950) But what is the condition of the Congress now?

('95', 118, 2, 21, 239519) It would be a misfortune if the spirit of service disappears and everyone thinks only of grabbing a share out of the crores of rupees.
('95', 118, 2, 22, 239654) It would be no service to the nation if devoid of the spirit of service we concern ourselves only with serving our own ends or those of our relatives and friends by seeking the favours of the Chief Minister or by capturing the Congress office to further our own interest.
('95', 118, 2, 23, 239926) Everywhere Congressmen are thus scrambling for power and favours.
('95', 118, 2, 24, 239992) This is true not only of Bihar but of all provinces.
('95', 118, 2, 25, 240045) If this continues, I am afraid, we shall not be able to hold the reins of the Congress firmly, nor will those who are in the Government be able to run it efficiently.
('95', 118, 2, 26, 240212) A government seems to have only military power behind it, but it cannot run on the strength of that power alone.
('95', 118, 2, 27, 240325) What is the real power of the Government?
('95', 118, 2, 28, 240367) The real power is in your hands.
('95', 118, 2, 29, 240400) Their power is only what you delegate to them.

('95', 118, 2, 31, 240519) It is a different matter if you fail to recognize your own strength and remain in darkness.

('95', 128, 1, 2, 259374) 133. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 128, 2, 3, 259404) MANER, May 23, 1947 About eight hundred years ago Saint Makhdum Maneri lived in Maner.
('95', 128, 2, 4, 259491) Though communal tension did prevail here, with the efforts of the Congressmen Maner was spared the devastation that follows a riot.
('95', 128, 2, 5, 259623) As I had said 1 [the day before] yesterday, since most of our social problems are inter related I cannot help mentioning other problems along with my present task of rehabilitating the people who had fled to other places.
('95', 128, 2, 6, 259845) Take for instance the question of the zamindars.
('95', 128, 2, 7, 259894) You all know that the century old reign of the white indigo planters was brought to an end by the will and concerted action of all the people and their leaders, prominent among whom were the late Brijkishore Babu and Rajendra Babu.
('95', 128, 2, 8, 260126) But I have been told that the tyranny of the white rulers is being continued even today by the Indian zamindars.
('95', 128, 2, 9, 260239) They exploit their ryots economically, terrorize them through their officials and escape due punishment through collusion with the authorities.
('95', 128, 2, 10, 260383) If it is true, the zamindars are digging their own graves.
('95', 128, 2, 11, 260442) They can survive only if they become trustees of their ryots.
('95', 128, 2, 12, 260504) But as a devotee of truth and justice I must discuss the other side of the problem as presented to me by the zamindars.
('95', 128, 2, 13, 260624) Because of my friendship with all, the zamindars also regard me as a friend, although they know my identification with the masses.
('95', 128, 2, 14, 260755) They tell me that with the Congress coming into power and drawing its sanction from the masses the ryots feel that they can commit all sorts of excesses, dispossess the zamindars of their entire property, destroy their crops and terrorize them by other acts of violence.
('95', 128, 2, 15, 261026) Similarly, under the influence of false propaganda, labourers in the mills think that they can become the masters of the mills by damaging them.
('95', 128, 2, 16, 261171) As one of the masses I can only say to the peasants and labourers that they are only harming their own cause by following this senseless policy.
('95', 128, 2, 17, 261316) They constitute the real masses and they should realize their own strength.
('95', 128, 2, 18, 261392) In a mad fury, the millions can easily destroy the handful of zamindars but ultimately their madness would bring about their own ruin.
('95', 128, 3, 19, 261527) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 21 5 1947
('95', 129, 0, 1, 261571) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 129, 1, 2, 261613) I have heard destructive criticism of the Government by the
('95', 129, 2, 3, 261673) people who can neither wield the power that has come to the nation nor let others who deserve wield it.
('95', 129, 2, 4, 261777) The ministers on the other hand should be true servants of the people from whom they derive their power.
('95', 129, 2, 5, 261882) They should not show any partiality while allocating jobs to the candidates, should be free from the evil of bribery and mete out equal justice to all.

('95', 131, 7, 14, 266416) We may attain complete independence in the coming few days.
('95', 131, 7, 15, 266476) However precious political independence may be, we should not rest quiet till something tangible is done in terms of national welfare.

('95', 131, 7, 17, 266769) Whatever may be the desire of the British or any other nation, it is not possible now to delay our independence which is
('95', 131, 8, 18, 266890) 1 Enclosing a copy of the draft proposal for United Sovereign Bengal the addressee had sought Gandhiji’s “help and guidance” in securing an agreement between the Congress and the Muslim League; vide also pp.

('95', 132, 0, 1, 267514) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 133
('95', 132, 1, 2, 267555) just round the corner.
('95', 132, 1, 3, 267578) If we are not vigilant in the intervening period, our condition will be like that of a typhoid patient.
('95', 132, 1, 4, 267682) We nurse the typhoid patient while he is running temperature.
('95', 132, 1, 5, 267744) But he needs to be really looked after only after the fever has come down.
('95', 132, 1, 6, 267819) If the patient does not have proper care after his fever has come down he suffers a relapse and faces the danger of death.
('95', 132, 1, 7, 267942) Such is going to be the period immediately after independence.

('95', 132, 1, 9, 268108) We shall have to be large hearted.

('95', 134, 1, 2, 272180) Today many people are beginning to fell that a clash, possibly of a violent character, with the supporters of the League is inevitable.

('95', 136, 5, 7, 277064) 140. LETTER TO JULIAN HUXLEY 2
('95', 136, 6, 8, 277095) May 25, 1947
('95', 136, 7, 9, 277108) DEAR DR.
('95', 136, 7, 10, 277117) JULIAN HUXLEY, As I am constantly on the move, I never get my post in time.
('95', 136, 7, 11, 277193) But for your letter to Pandit Nehru in which you referred to your letter to me, I might have missed your letter.
('95', 136, 7, 12, 277306) But I see that you have given your addressees ample time to enable them to give their replies.
('95', 136, 7, 13, 277401) I am writing this in a moving train.
('95', 136, 7, 14, 277438) It will be posted tomorrow when I reach Delhi.
('95', 136, 7, 15, 277485) I am afraid I can’t give you anything approaching your minimum.
('95', 136, 7, 16, 277549) That I have no time for the effort is true enough.
('95', 136, 7, 17, 277600) But what is truer is that I am a poor reader of literature past or present, much as I should like to read some of its gems.
('95', 136, 7, 18, 277724) Living a stormy life since my early youth, I had no leisure to do the necessary reading.
('95', 136, 7, 19, 277813) I learnt from my illiterate but wise mother that all rights to be deserved and preserved came from duty well done.
('95', 136, 7, 20, 277928) Thus the very right to live accrues to us only when we do the duty of citizenship of the world.
('95', 136, 7, 21, 278024) From this one fundamental statement, perhaps it is easy enough to define the duties of man and woman and correlate every right to some corresponding duty to be first performed.
('95', 136, 7, 22, 278201) Every other right can be shown to be usurpation hardly worth fighting for.
('95', 136, 7, 23, 278276) I wonder if it is too late to revise the idea of defining the rights of man apart from his duty.

('95', 137, 4, 26, 280313) 142. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 137, 5, 27, 280343) NEW DELHI May 25, 1947
('95', 137, 6, 28, 280366) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, You know that we should maintain silence during the prayer.
('95', 137, 6, 29, 280448) You gave me the taste of peace here and your example is followed by
('95', 137, 7, 30, 280516) 1 Minister in the Interim Government for Industries and Supplies
('95', 138, 0, 1, 280581) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 139
('95', 138, 1, 2, 280622) people everywhere.
('95', 138, 1, 3, 280641) You will be glad to know that in Bengal this time even huge prayer meetings were peaceful.
('95', 138, 1, 4, 280732) Usually when I am travelling crowds gather and people, out of affection, raise loud slogans.
('95', 138, 1, 5, 280825) I do appreciate this affection but now my health cannot stand the din.
('95', 138, 1, 6, 280896) I am grateful to you that in spite of the disturbances you maintained silence at the previous prayer meetings and set a good example to others.
('95', 138, 1, 7, 281040) Prayer meetings in Bihar were also as peaceful as in Bengal.
('95', 138, 1, 8, 281101) In Bihar people gathered in much larger numbers.
('95', 138, 1, 9, 281150) I am not now physically strong enough to travel far in this terrible heat.
('95', 138, 1, 10, 281225) Hence in Bihar I travelled for an hour or an hour and a half by train or car, and went to different places where we used to have prayers.
('95', 138, 1, 11, 281363) In one place by a river bank more than a lakh of people had gathered.
('95', 138, 1, 12, 281433) Every little while fresh crowds arrived and raised cries of ‘jai’.
('95', 138, 1, 13, 281500) There was so much noise that I could not hold the prayer.
('95', 138, 1, 14, 281558) But barring this one place, I could hold regular prayers at every place in Bihar.
('95', 138, 1, 15, 281640) The gatherings in Bihar tended to be larger than those in Bengal.
('95', 138, 1, 16, 281706) The people of Bihar knew me but still came round to have a look at me.
('95', 138, 1, 17, 281777) We are 400 million people and how long can we remember an individual by seeing and hearing him only for a while?
('95', 138, 1, 18, 281890) People are always eager to see me.
('95', 138, 1, 19, 281925) They wonder what Gandhi looks like.
('95', 138, 1, 20, 281961) They want to see if he is a creature with a tail and horns.
('95', 138, 1, 21, 282021) Thus people used to gather in huge numbers.
('95', 138, 1, 22, 282065) The Muslims were so few there that the Hindus could well have clamoured that they would not hear any prayer in Arabic.
('95', 138, 1, 23, 282184) But not a single person in such large gatherings said any such thing.
('95', 138, 1, 24, 282254) Why should anyone have said so?
('95', 138, 1, 25, 282286) Why may not one recite from the Koran?
('95', 138, 1, 26, 282325) You too are maintaining silence here.

('95', 138, 1, 29, 282498) I thought that in the name of non violence it was leading to violence.
('95', 138, 1, 30, 282569) I did not pay any attention to him.
('95', 138, 1, 31, 282605) He realized the situation and kept quiet.

('95', 145, 1, 2, 295112) 148. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 145, 2, 3, 295142) NEW DELHI, Monday, May 26, 1947 I had written out the speech for today.
('95', 145, 2, 4, 295214) Then after 5 p.m.
('95', 145, 2, 5, 295232) or so I received a letter from the lady who had objected yesterday saying that I had broken my promise by holding the prayers.
('95', 145, 2, 6, 295359) This was farthest from my thoughts.
('95', 145, 2, 7, 295395) I appealed to you and called upon you to hold yourselves in restraint in order to protect the objectors and you agreed to have the prayer.
('95', 145, 2, 8, 295534) It will be discourtesy on my part if I do not hold the prayers because of such obstruction.
('95', 145, 2, 9, 295626) Generosity in that case would amount to avarice.
('95', 145, 2, 10, 295675) That is not how ahimsa works.
('95', 145, 2, 11, 295705) The lady, therefore, should forgive me, for the prayer will go on.
('95', 145, 2, 12, 295772) I must repeat what I told you yesterday.
('95', 145, 2, 13, 295813) Public prayer is a precious duty.
('95', 145, 2, 14, 295847) It cannot be lightly thrown away.
('95', 145, 2, 15, 295881) One who objects to it commits a crime, but it is good to pray silently if there is a possibility of the objector being molested.
('95', 145, 2, 16, 296010) You responded to my entreaty by maintaining complete peace and order and did not molest the objectors but when I felt that this restraint was being abused I decided to follow the other course.
('95', 145, 2, 17, 296203) I was glad that the lady who had objected remained calm.
('95', 145, 2, 18, 296260) Whatever be her own opinion.
('95', 145, 2, 19, 296289) I hope she will maintain her composure.
('95', 145, 2, 20, 296329) One must at least observe a minimum of decorum.
('95', 145, 2, 21, 296377) I would like you to continue the prayers in future in spite of the objectors but at the same time you should be generous with them instead of being angry.
('95', 145, 2, 22, 296532) I had told you yesterday that it was unbecoming on our part to keep looking towards London.
('95', 145, 2, 23, 296624) The British cannot give us our freedom.
('95', 145, 2, 24, 296664) They can only get off our backs.
('95', 145, 2, 25, 296697) This they have already promised to do.
('95', 145, 2, 26, 296736) But it is for us to safeguard our freedom and give it a concrete shape.
('95', 145, 2, 27, 296808) How should we bring this about?
('95', 145, 2, 28, 296840) In my opinion we are unable to think coherently whilst the British rule continues in India.
('95', 145, 2, 29, 296932) It is not for the British Government to change the map of India.
('95', 145, 2, 30, 296997) All it has to do is to withdraw from India, if possible in an orderly manner, maybe even in chaos, but withdraw in any case on or before the date it has itself fixed.
('95', 145, 2, 31, 297164) There is an additional reason why no vital change in the map of India is possible in the present state of the country.

('95', 146, 7, 17, 298823) May 27, 1947
('95', 146, 8, 18, 298836) The very idea of partitioning the country is frightening.

('95', 146, 8, 20, 299046) Even partition may be tolerated, but I cannot bear the thought that it should be imposed by the British.

('95', 147, 1, 2, 299385) party intervene in a dispute between us brothers?
('95', 147, 1, 3, 299435) Are we not strong enough even to solve our own problems?
('95', 147, 1, 4, 299492) It is this which makes me feel that our ahimsa was not the ahimsa of the strong but something else.
('95', 147, 1, 5, 299592) But God has opened my eyes today.

('95', 147, 1, 19, 300742) I do not fully agree with the idea that it will happen when we have power in our hands or that we can do a great deal through power.
('95', 147, 1, 20, 300875) No doubt transfer of power will remove many obstacles.
('95', 147, 1, 21, 300930) But we shall have to do solid work among the people.
('95', 147, 1, 22, 300983) Since you look upon me as an adviser and seek my advice of your own free will, I have only one advice to give, and that is that, if you wish to establish socialism, there is only one way in which it can be done : go and live among the poor in the villages, live as they live, be one with the village people, work for eight hours daily, use only village made goods and articles even in your personal lives, remove illiteracy among the village people, eradicate untouchability and uplift the women.
('95', 147, 1, 23, 301480) I will even go so far as to suggest that you should establish such a living bond with the village people that, if anyone amongst you is unmarried and wishes to marry, he or she should choose a partner from among the village girls or boys.
('95', 147, 1, 24, 301719) It anybody else seeks your advice on this subject, give him or her, too, the same advice.
('95', 147, 1, 25, 301809) Make your life an ideal one in this way; when the people see your transparent lives every minute of the day as clearly as we see pictures on a screen, their influence will be felt throu ghout the country and reform its life.
('95', 147, 1, 26, 302034) The Congress will soon have power in its hands, but the Congress is not wedded to an exclusive doctrine and
('95', 148, 0, 1, 302142) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 149
('95', 148, 1, 2, 302183) does not belong to any one party.
('95', 148, 1, 3, 302217) Tolerance for all points of view still remains its principle.

('95', 148, 1, 5, 302657) Jawaharlal will even congratulate you with all his heart.
('95', 148, 1, 6, 302715) I am, however, pained to say that, instead of doing such constructive work, what you are doing today is to incite the people and call for strikes.
