('95', 148, 1, 24, 304295) If the British leave and at the same time the people are given a new life through such education, I am confident that in five years India will be a leading country in Asia.
('95', 148, 2, 25, 304468) Q. Why do you oppose the growth of industries in our country through machinery?
('95', 148, 3, 26, 304548) A. You can use machines to manufacture cars, engines, aeroplanes and things of that kind.
('95', 148, 3, 27, 304638) But I am strongly opposed to the use of machines for grinding corn, manufacturing cloth and ploug hing the land.
('95', 148, 3, 28, 304751) The consumption of mill ground flour has deprived us
('95', 149, 0, 1, 304804) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 149, 1, 2, 304846) of all vitality, for machine grinding destroys all the vitamins.
('95', 149, 1, 3, 304911) In the old days in Kathiawar we didn’t have even water taps.
('95', 149, 1, 4, 304972) The women used to fetch water from the river,with shining pots resting on supports studded with bright beads; it would be early morning and the women thus had a sun bath daily and that kept them healthy.
('95', 149, 1, 5, 305176) They used to grind the corn in the early dawn, singing bhajans the while, including prayers to God.
('95', 149, 1, 6, 305276) These simple innocent songs contai ning useful moral wisdom taught them some music and [the grinding] provided them exercise.
('95', 149, 1, 7, 305402) Afterwards the whole family would go to work in the fields, so that hardly anybody knew what illnes was or even the names of the diseases of lungs so widespread these days.
('95', 149, 1, 8, 305575) In such a vast country, or say, rather, a family, containing a variety of communities and races, there is no need for machinery at all.
('95', 149, 1, 9, 305711) Mach inery does the work in very little time and that is harmful in every way, physically and economically.
('95', 149, 1, 10, 305819) With so much leisure on hand, the people get busy in mischief, for, as the saying is, an idle mind is the devil’s workshop.

('95', 155, 4, 8, 319152) 153. LETTER TO A FOREIGN NATUROPATH 1 [May 28, 1947] 2
('95', 155, 5, 9, 319207) You will be pleased to know that I became a confirmed convert to natue cure when I read Kuhne’s New Science of Healing and Just’s Return to Nature over forty years ago.
('95', 155, 5, 10, 319376) I must confess that I have not been able fully to follow the meaning of ‘return to nature’ not because of want of will but because of my ignorance.
('95', 155, 5, 11, 319524) I am now trying to evolve a system of nature cure suited to the millions of India’s poor.
('95', 155, 5, 12, 319614) I try to confine myself to the propagation of such cure as is derivable from the use of earth, water, light, air and the great void.
('95', 155, 5, 13, 319747) This naturally leads man to know that the sovereign cure of all ills is the recitation from the heart of the name of God whom some millions here know by the name of Rama and the other millions by the name of Allah.
('95', 155, 5, 14, 319962) Such recitation from the heart carries with it the obligation to recognize and follow the laws which nature has ordained for man.
('95', 155, 5, 15, 320092) This train of reasoning leads one to the conclusi on that prevention is better than cure.
('95', 155, 5, 16, 320182) Therefore, one is irresistibly driven to inculcating the laws of hygiene, i.e., of cleanliness of the mind, of the body and of one’s surroundings.
('95', 155, 6, 17, 320329) Harijan, 15 6 1947
('95', 155, 7, 18, 320348) 154. LETTER TO A NATUROPATH May 28, 1947 I appreciate your enthusiasm.

('95', 158, 5, 8, 325214) BALVANTSINHA, I have your letter.

('95', 158, 8, 21, 325802) LO CHI LUEN 1
('95', 158, 9, 22, 325816) May 28, 1947
('95', 158, 10, 23, 325829) LO CHI LUEN:] How do you think things will shape themselves?
('95', 158, 10, 24, 325890) How do you predict the future?
('95', 158, 10, 25, 325921) [GANDHIJI:] I am an irrepressible optimist.
('95', 158, 10, 26, 325965) We have not lived and toiled in vain all these years that we should become barbarians as we appear to be becoming, looking at all the senseless bloodshed in Bengal, Bihar and the Punjab.
('95', 158, 10, 27, 326152) But I feel it is just an indication that as we are throwing off the foreign yoke all the dirt and froth is coming to the surface.
('95', 158, 10, 28, 326282) When the Ganges is in flood, the water is turbid.
('95', 158, 10, 29, 326332) The dirt comes to the surface.
('95', 158, 10, 30, 326363) When the flood subsides, you see the clear blue water which soothes the eye.
('95', 158, 10, 31, 326440) That is what I hope for and live for.
('95', 158, 10, 32, 326478) I do not wish to live to see Indian humanity becoming barbarian.
('95', 158, 10, 33, 326543) And who can predict the future?
('95', 158, 10, 34, 326575) Years ago I read Butler’s

('95', 165, 4, 14, 340588) 162. ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS May 29, 1947
('95', 165, 5, 15, 340627) When we do not get enough food in spite of very hard work, what should we do?
('95', 165, 5, 16, 340705) It is an eternal law that anybody who does useful work must get enough to eat.
('95', 165, 5, 17, 340784) But when that does not happen, it may be assumed that there is something wrong in the working of the Govern ment.
('95', 165, 5, 18, 340898) But in the changed times now we cannot meet this [situation] by looting Government shops or starting riots, for we ourselves will have to suffer because of the resulting loss.
('95', 165, 5, 19, 341074) Instead, the people may pea cefully sit down in front of the shops and, as a last resort, fast indefinitely.
('95', 165, 5, 20, 341183) But this weapon should be employed only after careful thinking, for these days people have made this sacred weapon very cheap.
('95', 165, 5, 21, 341310) In any case it should never be employed to gain a personal end.
('95', 165, 6, 22, 341374) Probably you know that your statues are being set up and your photographs unveiled at many places.
('95', 165, 6, 23, 341473) What do you think about this?
('95', 165, 6, 24, 341503) How can I say I do not know that my statues are being erected and my photographs are being unveiled everywhere in the country, that they are garlanded and lights are waved before them?
('95', 165, 6, 25, 341688) But I attach no importance to these things, for I dislike such things intensely.
('95', 165, 6, 26, 341769) They are a sheer waste of money.
('95', 165, 6, 27, 341802) And I strongly fell that these activities do me no honour but, on the contrary, are an affront to me.
('95', 165, 6, 28, 341904) If the people wish to honour me, let them honour the charkha, that is, spin daily by way of yajna.
('95', 165, 6, 29, 342003) That will be as good as honouring me.
('95', 165, 6, 30, 342041) Let them also read the Gita and meditate over its teaching.
('95', 165, 6, 31, 342101) And if they cannot do even that, let them just repeat Ramanama.
('95', 165, 6, 32, 342165) To understand a man’s virtues and follow his principles in one’s own life is as good as honouring the man himself.
('95', 165, 6, 33, 342280) I know full well what labour
('95', 166, 0, 1, 342309) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 167
('95', 166, 1, 2, 342350) it costs to set up statues of a living man or unveil his photographs, to distribute sweets after the ceremony and to make the function a success at great expense.

('95', 192, 1, 2, 401990) 178. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING DELHI, Monday, June 2, 1947 I am unable to tell you what has happened or is happening on the political plane.
('95', 192, 1, 3, 402130) But I would like to repeat what I have been saying these last three or four days, namely, that the common man should not concern himself with what the Viceroy has brought from England.
('95', 192, 1, 4, 402315) We should concern ourselves with what our duty should be in any situa tion that may arise.
('95', 192, 1, 5, 402406) The one thing the country should make clear is that it will accept nothing through force.
('95', 192, 1, 6, 402496) Continuing, therefore, the thought that I have been developing these last few days, I should like to ask what our doctors and scientists are doing for the sake of the country.
('95', 192, 1, 7, 402672) One finds them readily going to foreign countries to learn new ideas and the latest treatments for curing diseases.
('95', 192, 1, 8, 402788) I would suggest that they should turn their attention to the seven lakhs of villages of India.
('95', 192, 1, 9, 402883) They will then find that all medical men and women can find work to do there.
('95', 192, 1, 10, 402961) Not in the Western fashion, of course, but in our own fashion in the villages.
('95', 192, 1, 11, 403040) They will then also know many indigenous remedies which they will be able to make use of.
('95', 192, 1, 12, 403130) There are so many herbs in India that we have no need to import drugs at all.
('95', 192, 1, 13, 403208) But more than through drugs they will help the people by teaching them the right mode of living.
('95', 192, 1, 14, 403305) What shall I say to the scientists?
('95', 192, 1, 15, 403341) Are they giving their attention to growing more food?
('95', 192, 1, 16, 403395) And this not with the aid of artificial fertilizers but through proper methods of tillage and by use of organic manure?
('95', 192, 1, 17, 403515) In Noakhali I saw people using even the water hyacinth which grows wild and blocks the flow of river water.
('95', 192, 1, 18, 403623) This our scientists will do when they learn to live for the country rather than for themselves.
('95', 192, 1, 19, 403719) I spoke yesterday of the invaluable work that Jawaharlal is doing.
('95', 192, 1, 20, 403786) I had described him as the uncrowned king of India.
('95', 192, 1, 21, 403838) He cannot be replaces today when the Englishmen are withdrawing their authorityfrom India.
('95', 192, 1, 22, 403929) He, who was educated at Harrow and Cambridge and became a barrister, is greatly needed to carry on the negotiations with the English men.
('95', 192, 1, 23, 404067) But the time is fast approaching when India will have to elect the first president of the Republic.
('95', 192, 1, 24, 404167) I would have propo sed the name of Chakrayya, had he been alive.
('95', 192, 1, 25, 404232) I would wish with all my heart to have a brave, selfless and pure hearted scavenger girl to
('95', 193, 0, 1, 404324) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 193, 1, 2, 404366) be our first President.
('95', 193, 1, 3, 404390) It is no vain dream.
('95', 193, 1, 4, 404411) We can certainly come across such Harijan girls if only we make an effort to find them.
('95', 193, 1, 5, 404499) Had I not selected little Gulnar, the late Maulana Mahomed Ali’s daug hter?
('95', 193, 1, 6, 404575) But the silly girl went and married Shuaib Qureshi.

('95', 217, 3, 4, 456766) Mr. Gandhi suggests that H. E. should speak to Mr. Jinnah in the following
('95', 217, 4, 5, 456841) sense : I am extremely anxious lest the referendum in N.W.F.P. should lead to bloodshed and blood feuds between brother and brother Pathan, and I have been wondering whether it could possibly be avoided.
('95', 217, 4, 6, 457045) Now that you have got your Pakistan, would it not be wise for you to go to the N.W.F.P. and speak to the people of the Province, of whatever party they may be, including the present Ministry and their followers?
('95', 217, 4, 7, 457257) You could explain what Pakistan which has hitherto been a vague expression, really is and present your case in an attrac tive manner, in the hope that you will be able to woo them to become a Province of Pakistan, with perfect freedom to frame their own Provincial constitution.
('95', 217, 5, 8, 457536) If you are successful in your persuasion, the proposed referen dum and all that it involves would be avoided.
('95', 217, 5, 9, 457646) If you felt disposed to adopt this suggestion, I could, I think, give you a positive assurance that the Khan Brothers and their followers would meet you as friends and give you an attentive hearing.
('95', 217, 6, 10, 457845) Mr. Gandhi asked that if this appeal to Mr. Jinnah was unsuccessful, he (Mr. Gandhi) might be informed of the fact, in order that he might consider the position again.
('95', 217, 6, 11, 458013) 3 Mr. Gandhi added that Abdul Ghaffar Khan was so anxious about the permanent blood feuds which would result from the referendum that he would go to almost any length, consistent with honour, to avoid it.
('95', 217, 6, 12, 458218) In the last resort, he would be prepared to advise his brother and his colleagues in the Ministry to resign, and then to ask the Viceroy to put the N. W. F. P. under Section 93.

('95', 228, 7, 20, 484059) A child goes from its mother’s lap to the cradle and from the cradle to the push cart till he becomes a man who has learnt to walk without aid.
('95', 228, 7, 21, 484203) To cling to the aid when it is needless is surely harmful.
('95', 228, 7, 22, 484262) I made it clear last week that brahmacharya is one out of the

('95', 229, 1, 19, 485808) Yet I do not know what would be my state if I lost my way and had to wander alone in a thick forest on a dark night and if I were to forget that God was ever with me.
('95', 229, 1, 20, 485975) If this childhood fear has not completely gone from me, it would be certainly more difficult for me to be fearless in a lonely jungle than to control the sex urge.
('95', 229, 1, 21, 486139) There are certain rules laid down in India for the would be brahmachari.
('95', 229, 1, 22, 486212) Thus he may not live among women, animals and eunuchs, he may not teach a woman alone or even in a group, he may not sit on the same mat with a woman, he may not look at any part of a woman’s body, he may not take milk, curds, ghee or any fatty substance nor indulge in baths and oil massage.
('95', 229, 1, 23, 486505) I read about these when I was in South Africa.
('95', 229, 1, 24, 486552) There I came in touch with some men and women who, while they observed brahmacharya, never knew that any of the above named restraints were necessary.
('95', 229, 1, 25, 486703) Nor did I observe them and I was none the worse for the non observance.
('95', 229, 1, 26, 486775) I did give up milk, ghee and other animal substances but for different reasons.

('95', 229, 1, 28, 486922) But if today I could find any effective vegetable substitute for milk and ghee, I would gladly renounce all animal products.

('95', 230, 1, 2, 487115) A perfect brahmachari never loses his vital fluid.
('95', 230, 1, 3, 487166) On the contrary, he is able to increase it day by day and, what is more, he conserves it; he will, therefore, never become old in the accepted sense and his intellect will never be dimmed.
('95', 230, 1, 4, 487355) It appears to me that even the true aspirant does not need the above mentioned restraints.

('95', 243, 3, 14, 513041) 227. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 243, 4, 15, 513071) NEW DELHI, June 9, 1947 I have received some letters saying that Allopanishad about which I had talked to you some days ago is not to be found in any collection of religious writings.
('95', 243, 4, 16, 513255) I had mentioned this work from memory so I consulted a friend 1 and he has written to say that the collection I have in mind does mention Allopanishad, saying it has seven mantras.

('95', 252, 5, 12, 532565) 1. As to the referendum in the Frontier Province I must confess that my idea does not commend itself to Pandit Nehru and his colleagues.

('95', 268, 7, 25, 566648) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, When I was walking around in Noakhali I saw that people were very frightened.
('95', 268, 7, 26, 566748) And frightened poeple cannot think of God.
('95', 268, 7, 27, 566791) Then we had to pass through villages and find our way along narrow tracks round the fields—something which few men and women in Noakhali ever did.
('95', 268, 7, 28, 566938) But the experience I gained from this walking tour I could not have gained otherwise.
('95', 268, 7, 29, 567024) We had to pass through the fields owned
('95', 269, 0, 1, 567064) 270 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 269, 1, 2, 567106) by both Hindus and Muslims.
('95', 269, 1, 3, 567134) So we uttered both names of God as we walked.
('95', 269, 1, 4, 567180) When God is here, there and everywhere God must be one.

('95', 269, 1, 6, 567359) That is why I had posed the question whether those calling God Rahim would have to leave Hindustan—of course now we must give up calling the country Hindustan—and whether in the part described as Pakistan Rama as the name of God would be forbidden.
('95', 269, 1, 7, 567608) Would someone who called God Krishna be turned out of Pakistan?

('95', 285, 1, 2, 602339) 264. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 285, 2, 3, 602369) NEW DELHI, June 15, 1947
('95', 285, 3, 4, 602394) I am sorry that today my silence has to begin earlier than usual, because tomorrow afternoon there is going to be a meeting of the Working Committee.
('95', 285, 3, 5, 602544) I therefore give you my message in writing.
('95', 285, 3, 6, 602588) I have had letters from various countries asking me one question which I wish to answer today through this message.
('95', 285, 3, 7, 602704) The question in brief is: ‘Why is it that in your country political parties take recourse to violence to gain political ends?
('95', 285, 3, 8, 602830) Day by day violence continues to increase in your country.
('95', 285, 3, 9, 602889) Can you explain why?
('95', 285, 3, 10, 602910) For thirty years you fought the British non violently.
('95', 285, 3, 11, 602965) Why does it end up thus?
('95', 285, 3, 12, 602990) Would you still want to give the world the message of non violence?’ In answering the question I have to confess my bankruptcy.
('95', 285, 3, 13, 603118) However, ahimsa can never suffer bankruptcy.
('95', 285, 3, 14, 603163) As I have explained the ahimsa which we have practised during the last earlier thirty years has been the ahimsa of the weak.
('95', 285, 3, 15, 603288) Whether this view of mine is valid or not you will judge for yourselves.
('95', 285, 3, 16, 603361) What has to be admitted is that in the changed conditions of today the ahimsa of the weak has no place.
('95', 285, 3, 17, 603465) The truth is that India has not so far had an opportunity to practise the ahimsa of the brave.
('95', 285, 3, 18, 603560) Nothing is gained by my repeating that no power in the world can stand before the ahimsa of the brave.
('95', 285, 3, 19, 603663) For the truth of this can only be proved by repeatedly and extensively manifesting it in life.
('95', 285, 3, 20, 603758) So far as I can I have endeavoured to manifest it in my life.
('95', 285, 3, 21, 603820) But maybe I am not fully qualified, maybe I am a beggar.
('95', 285, 3, 22, 603877) Why then should I ask you to follow me when I am not able to show results?
('95', 285, 3, 23, 603952) The question is pertinent and my answer is simple.
('95', 285, 3, 24, 604003) I ask no one to follow me.
('95', 285, 3, 25, 604030) Each should go by the voice within.
('95', 285, 3, 26, 604066) If you cannot hear the voice within you may do as you like.
('95', 285, 3, 27, 604126) In any case you must on no account blindly follow anybody.
('95', 285, 3, 28, 604185) Another important question is that, if I am fully convinced that India is following the path of error, why do I associate with those who are in error?
('95', 285, 3, 29, 604336) Why do I not go my own way in the faith that if I am on the right path my old co workers will all return to me?
('95', 285, 3, 30, 604448) I like the question.
('95', 285, 3, 31, 604469) I shall not argue against it.
('95', 285, 3, 32, 604499) I will merely say that my faith and my creed are as they were.
('95', 285, 3, 33, 604562) They have not weakened.
('95', 285, 3, 34, 604586) It is possible that my method was wrong.
('95', 285, 3, 35, 604627) When one is in a difficulty old experiences and old patterns help but one should not become merely
('95', 286, 0, 1, 604726) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 287
('95', 286, 1, 2, 604767) mechanical.
('95', 286, 1, 3, 604779) I further request all those who wish to advise me that they should have patience with me and above all they should join me in the faith that to ameliorate the pains of this suffering world there is no way save that of ahimsa, however arduous it may be.
('95', 286, 1, 4, 605032) Millions like me may not be able to practise this in life.
('95', 286, 1, 5, 605091) For this they themselves will be to blame, not ahimsa.
('95', 286, 1, 6, 605146) I may here mention another matter to you.
('95', 286, 1, 7, 605188) Although I am observing silence, some friends from Travancore came to see me.
('95', 286, 1, 8, 605266) They assured me that there was not the least bit of exaggeration in what I had been saying concerning that State.

('95', 286, 1, 10, 605521) The voice of the people there is being throttled.

('95', 286, 3, 18, 606071) 265. A LETTER June 16, 1947 Every day all kinds of reports keep appearing in newspapers.

('95', 287, 2, 3, 606777) NEW DELHI, June 16, 1947
('95', 287, 3, 4, 606802) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, This morning when I was observing silence, Shri Purusho ttamdas Tandon paid me a visit.
('95', 287, 3, 5, 606912) I have told you how I was pained by Tandonji’s statement that every man and woman should carry arms.
('95', 287, 3, 6, 607013) A correspondent had asked me how I, a votary of the Gita, could feel hurt.
('95', 287, 3, 7, 607088) The letter also said that Tandonji believed in the principle of tit for tat.
('95', 287, 3, 8, 607165) I asked Tandonji about it.
('95', 287, 3, 9, 607192) Tandonji explained that although he did not believe in the principle of tit for tat, he certainly believed that everyone should carry arms for self defence.
('95', 287, 3, 10, 607349) This he said was also the teaching of the Gita.
('95', 287, 3, 11, 607397) I told Tandonji that he should at least write to the friend and explain that he did not believe in the principle of tit for tat so that he should not labour under a misapprehension.
('95', 287, 3, 12, 607579) I do not believe that the Gita advocates violence for self defence.
('95', 287, 3, 13, 607647) I understand the Gita differently.
('95', 287, 3, 14, 607682) If the Gita or some other Sanskrit work advocates this I am not prepared to accept it as Shastra.
('95', 287, 3, 15, 607780) An utterance does not become scriptural merely because it is couched in Sanskrit.
('95', 287, 3, 16, 607862) Tandonji reminded me that I had advised the killing of the monkeys which ravaged fields or otherwise caused harm.
('95', 287, 3, 17, 607976) I do not like to kill any living thing, not even an ant.
('95', 287, 3, 18, 608033) But the question of fields is a different question and people differ.
('95', 287, 3, 19, 608103) Tandonji said we might not adopt the principle of tit for tat or a tooth for a tooth and a slap for a slap.
('95', 287, 3, 20, 608211) But if we did not take up arms and show our strength how were we to defend ourselves?
('95', 287, 3, 21, 608297) My answer is that self defence is necessary; but how does one defend oneself?
('95', 287, 3, 22, 608375) If someone comes to me and says, ‘Will you or will you not utter Ramanama?
('95', 287, 3, 23, 608450) If you do not, look at this sword.’ Then I shall say that although I am uttering Ramanama every moment I will not do so at the point of the sword.
('95', 287, 3, 24, 608597) Thus I shall risk my life in self defence.
('95', 287, 3, 25, 608640) Now if I recite the Kalma I do not lose my religion.
('95', 287, 3, 26, 608693) What does it matter if I say in Arabic that Allah is one and that Mohammed is His only Prophet!
('95', 287, 3, 27, 608789) There is no sin in saying this and if by my merely saying this they accept me as a Muslim, I shall consider it a matter of pride.
('95', 287, 3, 28, 608919) But if someone comes to me and wants to make me recite the
('95', 288, 0, 1, 608978) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 289
('95', 288, 1, 2, 609019) Kalma at the point of the sword I will never do so.
('95', 288, 1, 3, 609071) I will defend myself with my life.
('95', 288, 1, 4, 609106) I want to stay alive to prove this paradox.
('95', 288, 1, 5, 609150) I do not wish to stay alive in any other way.
('95', 288, 1, 6, 609196) I have said that geographically our land may very well be divided but that our hearts should not be divided.
('95', 288, 1, 7, 609305) But who will listen to me?
('95', 288, 1, 8, 609332) The day was when everyone listened to Gandhi because Gandhi showed the way to fight the British.
('95', 288, 1, 9, 609429) And how many Britishers were here?
('95', 288, 1, 10, 609464) Only seventy five thousand.
('95', 288, 1, 11, 609492) But they had such resources, such might, that, as Annie Besant said, they answered brickbats with bullets and our violence was wholly ineffective.
('95', 288, 1, 12, 609639) Ahimsa promised to be more efficacious, so Gandhi was looked up to, but today they say that Gandhi cannot show the path and therefore arms should be taken up for self defence.
('95', 288, 1, 13, 609815) One can then only say that all these past thirty years that we spent in non violent struggle had been wasted.
('95', 288, 1, 14, 609925) We should have thrown out the British through violence.
('95', 288, 1, 15, 609981) But I do not think that the thirty years were wasted.
('95', 288, 1, 16, 610035) It was good that under the severest oppression we remained non violent.
('95', 288, 1, 17, 610107) They used their arms against us.
('95', 288, 1, 18, 610140) But we were not cowed down and the message of the Congress spread throughout the length and breadth of India.
('95', 288, 1, 19, 610250) Only it did not penetrate the seven lakh villages of India because our ahimsa was the ahimsa of the impotent.

('95', 289, 1, 28, 613540) They cannot have all that they were given under the British regime.

('95', 296, 3, 5, 626110) 276. A TALK NEW DELHI, June 18, 1947 If people start fasting over every little thing right from now, what is going to happen later?
('95', 296, 3, 6, 626242) For my part I shall certainly plead with them 1, try to make them see reason, but if, nevertheless, they fast I am not going to yield even if they come to the verge of death.
('95', 296, 3, 7, 626417) Because even that is a test of my truth and non violence.
('95', 296, 3, 8, 626475) To yield to a wrong thing out of fear is also a kind of lie and violence.
('95', 296, 3, 9, 626549) A devotee of truth and non violence remains steadfast even if the whole world goes against him.
('95', 296, 3, 10, 626645) Only then can he propagate the principles of truth and non violence.
('95', 296, 3, 11, 626714) Who knows that God is not thus testing me?
('95', 296, 3, 12, 626757) But I feel that Hindus themselves are responsible for subverting Hinduism.
('95', 296, 3, 13, 626832) How can there be peace when there is no unity?
('95', 296, 3, 14, 626879) There are so many castes and sub castes among Hindus.
('95', 296, 3, 15, 626933) Why, they have even separate festivals.
('95', 296, 3, 16, 626973) I remember there is a festival called Shitala Satam 2 in the month of Shravan.
('95', 296, 3, 17, 627052) My mother used to say that Shravan Sud Satam 3 was of Kanabis and Shravan Vad Satam 4 was ours.
('95', 296, 3, 18, 627148) I can cite many such differences.
('95', 296, 3, 19, 627182) These so called small things have a profound impact on the people and make them feel that they are separate from others.
('95', 296, 3, 20, 627303) That is why I say that the scholars, poets and writers of today should try to stamp out such bad customs and do their best to promote unity through their speech, thought and deed.
('95', 296, 3, 21, 627483) Such customs were perhaps appropriate for the period in which they originated.
('95', 296, 3, 22, 627562) But now we must get out of the rut.
('95', 296, 3, 23, 627598) And religious leaders, writers, poets and scholars should lead the way.
('95', 296, 3, 24, 627670) If that happens people will slowly come nearer to each other and, if they do so outwardly, they will automatically come nearer mentally also.
('95', 296, 3, 25, 627812) [From Gujarati]
('95', 296, 4, 26, 627828) Bihar Pachhi Dilhi, pp.

('95', 297, 1, 2, 628078) 277. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING NEW DELHI, June 18, 1947
('95', 297, 2, 3, 628133) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I spoke to you yesterday about a friend and his wife who were fasting on the road outside Valmiki Mandir.
('95', 297, 2, 4, 628261) Today they have sent me a very respectful letter.
('95', 297, 2, 5, 628311) But the letter does not show wisdom.
('95', 297, 2, 6, 628348) They are young, I am old.
('95', 297, 2, 7, 628374) If I say that I possess a little wisdom they should accept my word.
('95', 297, 2, 8, 628442) They say they can see the wisdom of what I say but that their conscience will not let them give up their fast.
('95', 297, 2, 9, 628553) You must have heard of the Gita Rahasya written by Tilak.
('95', 297, 2, 10, 628611) It is so rich in thought that it needs to be studied again and again.
('95', 297, 2, 11, 628681) I read it in Yeravda jail.
('95', 297, 2, 12, 628708) True, I do not find myself in agreement with everything he says but the fact remains that Tilak was a great scholar and had a vast knowledge of Sanskrit literature.
('95', 297, 2, 13, 628873) It is a long time since I read this work and so I cannot remember his exact words.
('95', 297, 2, 14, 628956) But I shall tell you the substance of what he says.
('95', 297, 2, 15, 629008) I think what he says is right.
('95', 297, 2, 16, 629039) He says at one place that “conscience” is an appropriate word for the inner voice, but that when one says that one acts according to the promptings of one’s conscience it does not really mean that one acts according to the promptings of one’s inner voice.
('95', 297, 2, 17, 629295) According to the Vedic thought all creatures are endowed with conscience.
('95', 297, 2, 18, 629369) But in many people conscience is dormant, which is to say the inner voice is torpid.
('95', 297, 2, 19, 629454) How can it then be described as “conscience”?
('95', 297, 2, 20, 629500) According to our Shastras the inner voice awakens only when one follows yama niyamas and practises various other disciplines.
('95', 297, 2, 21, 629626) I have digested this teaching of Tilak well so that I am able to tell whether what is taken for the inner voice is really the inner voice or not.
('95', 297, 2, 22, 629772) If a voice told a thief, ‘kill that girl, cut off her limbs and take away her jewellery’, I would not say it was the still small voice within.
('95', 297, 2, 23, 629915) It would be sheer wickedness.
('95', 297, 2, 24, 629945) We are all today sunk in stupor.
('95', 297, 2, 25, 629978) It frequently occurs to us to kill innocent children.
('95', 297, 2, 26, 630032) But the prompting does not come from the inner voice.
('95', 297, 2, 27, 630086) Then I am an expert on fasting.
('95', 297, 2, 28, 630118) Some Jain friends had resorted to fasting merely because they were not able to get something which they wanted.
('95', 297, 2, 29, 630230) I persuaded them to terminate the fast.
('95', 297, 2, 30, 630270) I told you also how even a great scholar like Dharmanand Kosambi had given up fasting on my advice.
('95', 297, 2, 31, 630370) Kaka Kalelkar, who is here, tells me that just
('95', 298, 0, 1, 630417) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 299
('95', 298, 1, 2, 630458) before his death Dr. Kosambi had told him that I had been right in advising him to give up his fast.
('95', 298, 1, 3, 630559) So, as an expert on fasting, I advise the couple to terminate their fast if they can do so.
('95', 298, 1, 4, 630651) Three days should be enough.
('95', 298, 1, 5, 630680) You will have seen from the newspapers that I met Mr. Jinnah yesterday.
('95', 298, 1, 6, 630752) I could not tell you about this meeting before because such a meeting had not been mooted.
('95', 298, 1, 7, 630843) When I was at the Viceroy’s House, the Viceroy told me that Mr. Jinnah was present there and that I should see him.
('95', 298, 1, 8, 630959) Well, I could not have refused.
('95', 298, 1, 9, 630991) I am the kind of person who would not hesitate to visit Mr. Jinnah at his house.
('95', 298, 1, 10, 631072) We met and we agreed that it would be good if we also met Badshah Khan.
('95', 298, 1, 11, 631144) Then we were to see the Viceroy in the evening.
('95', 298, 1, 12, 631192) But Badshah Khan, like the humble man he is, had taken a bus to Deoband and it took him not three but five hours to get back and this meant that we could not see the Viceroy again in the evening.
('95', 298, 1, 13, 631388) The Viceroy has left Delhi today but he would have been happy if we could have met.
('95', 298, 1, 14, 631472) We therefore went to Lord Ismay at 4.30 in the afternoon.
('95', 298, 1, 15, 631530) Badshah Khan has now gone to see Mr. Jinnah at his residence and he is still with him.
('95', 298, 1, 16, 631617) Do not please build any great hopes on this.
('95', 298, 1, 17, 631662) But we can certainly hope that the wound that we have received in the shape of Pakistan can be prevented from becoming still deeper.
('95', 298, 1, 18, 631795) We can but strive.
('95', 298, 1, 19, 631814) The result is in the hands of God.
('95', 298, 1, 20, 631849) Let us pray that the effort may lead to a happy result.
('95', 298, 1, 21, 631905) What would be a happy result in this instance?

('95', 298, 1, 23, 632019) Pathans are a sword happy people.

('95', 298, 1, 25, 632117) From generation to generation vendetta rules their lives but Badshah Khan saw that they could defend themselves better by dying than by killing.

('95', 302, 4, 8, 638364) 283. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING NEW DELHI, June 19, 1947
('95', 302, 5, 9, 638419) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Yesterday at the end of the prayer meeting a friend asked me a question.
('95', 302, 5, 10, 638514) I told him to put it in writing, which he did.
('95', 302, 5, 11, 638561) But the slip of paper containing the question remained in someone’s pocket and when the garment was washed, the slip suffered in the process and when it reached my hands nothing could be made of it.
('95', 302, 5, 12, 638760) It is a matter of shame but the questioner is not present at the meeting so I do not know to whom I should express my apology.
('95', 302, 5, 13, 638887) What I told you yesterday about the couple fasting here for the last 3 or 4 days first made them somewhat angry.
('95', 302, 5, 14, 639000) How could I describe myself as an expert on fasting?
('95', 302, 5, 15, 639053) Why was I so proud?
('95', 302, 5, 16, 639073) But when I met them at 9 o’clock last evening I explained to them that if a man five foot tall claimed to be five foot tall he could not be called proud.
('95', 302, 5, 17, 639227) They had said it in the heat of the moment.
('95', 302, 5, 18, 639271) And they realized that rather than fast they should not in their hearts recognize the division of India.
('95', 302, 5, 19, 639376) They broke their fast with milk and fruit.
('95', 302, 5, 20, 639419) I congratulated them.
('95', 302, 5, 21, 639441) They asked me, “Tell us, how can we co operate with injustice ?” I said, “Give up the gains accruing from injustice.” We should not use coercion against anyone.
('95', 302, 5, 22, 639602) We should not benefit from injustice.
('95', 302, 5, 23, 639640) This is the path of non violence.
('95', 302, 5, 24, 639674) This is non co operation.
('95', 302, 5, 25, 639700) I had said yesterday that Badshah Khan was seeing Mr. Jinnah and that we should pray for the success of the meeting.
('95', 302, 5, 26, 639817) It may be asked what fruit our prayer has yielded.
('95', 302, 5, 27, 639868) I cannot tell you more than what Mr. Jinnah has stated in the newspapers.
('95', 302, 5, 28, 639942) He says that the talks were cordial.

('95', 309, 3, 18, 654701) 287. TOWARDS REALIZATION 1
('95', 309, 4, 19, 654728) What is the mark of him who has Rama enthroned in his heart?
('95', 309, 4, 20, 654789) If we do not know this, there is danger of Ramanama being much misinterpreted.
('95', 309, 4, 21, 654868) Some misinterpretation is already in existence.
('95', 309, 4, 22, 654916) Many sport rosaries and put the sacred mark on the forehead and vainly babble His name.
('95', 309, 4, 23, 655004) It may well be asked whether I am not adding to the current hypocrisy by continued insistence on Ramanama.
('95', 309, 4, 24, 655111) I must not be deterred by such forebodings.
('95', 309, 4, 25, 655155) Silence thus brought about is harmful.
('95', 309, 4, 26, 655194) The living voice of silence needs to be backed by prolonged heartfelt practice.
('95', 309, 4, 27, 655274) In the absence of such natural silence, we must try to know the marks of him who has Rama in his heart.
('95', 309, 4, 28, 655378) A devotee of Rama may be said to be the same as the steadfast one (sthitaprajna) of the Gita.
('95', 309, 4, 29, 655472) If one goes a little deeper it will be seen that a true devotee of God faithfully obeys the five elemental forces of nature.
('95', 309, 4, 30, 655597) If he so obeys, he will not fall ill.
('95', 309, 4, 31, 655635) If perchance he does, he will cure himself with the aid of the elements.
('95', 309, 4, 32, 655708) It is not for the dweller in the body to get the body cured anyhow—he who believes that he is nothing but body will naturally wander to the ends of the earth in order to cure the body of its ills.
('95', 309, 4, 33, 655905) But he who realizes that the soul is something apart from, though in the body, that it is imperishable in contrast to the perishable body, will not be perturbed nor mourn if the elements fail.
('95', 309, 4, 34, 656098) On the contrary he will welcome death
('95', 309, 5, 35, 656136) 1The Gujarati original appeared under the title ‘‘Marks of a Votary of Ramanama’’ in Harijanbandhu, which was published simultaneously with the source.
('95', 310, 0, 1, 656288) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 311
('95', 310, 1, 2, 656329) as a friend.
('95', 310, 1, 3, 656342) He will become his own healer instead of looking for medical men.
('95', 310, 1, 4, 656408) He will live in the consciousness of the soul within and look to the care, first and last, of the indweller.
('95', 310, 1, 5, 656517) Such a man will take God’s name with every breath.
('95', 310, 1, 6, 656568) His Rama will be awake even whilst the body is asleep.
('95', 310, 1, 7, 656623) Rama will always be with him in whatever he does.
('95', 310, 1, 8, 656673) The real death for such a devoted man will be the loss of this sacred companionship.
('95', 310, 1, 9, 656758) As an aid to keeping his Rama with him, he will take what the five elements have to give him.
('95', 310, 1, 10, 656852) That is to say, he will employ the simplest and easiest way of deriving all the benefit he can from earth, air, water, sunlight and ether.
('95', 310, 1, 11, 656991) This aid is not complementary of Ramanama.
('95', 310, 1, 12, 657034) It is but a means of its realization.
('95', 310, 1, 13, 657072) Ramanama does not in fact require any aid.
('95', 310, 1, 14, 657115) But to claim belief in Ramanama and at the same time to run to doctors do not go hand in hand.
('95', 310, 1, 15, 657210) A friend versed in religious lore who read my remarks on Ramanama some time ago wrote to say that Ramanama is an alchemy such as can transform the body.
('95', 310, 1, 16, 657363) The conservation of the vital energy has been likened to accumulated wealth, but it is in the power of Ramanama alone to make it a running stream of ever increasing spiritual strength ultimately making a fall impossible.
('95', 310, 1, 17, 657584) Just as the body cannot exist without blood, so the soul needs the matchless and pure strength of faith.
('95', 310, 1, 18, 657689) This strength can renovate the weakness of all man’s physical organs.

('95', 312, 1, 2, 660123) 290. FROM AMERICA 1
('95', 312, 2, 3, 660143) Mr. Richard Gregg writes from U. S. A.:
('95', 312, 3, 4, 660183) Today’s New York newspaper carries a dispatch from New Delhi stating that you have given up hope of living for 125 years and that there is no place for you in India because of the deluge of violence.
('95', 312, 3, 5, 660383) If this report is substantially correct, I beg you, please reconsider your attitude.
('95', 312, 3, 6, 660468) As I see the matter there is far more at stake than present violence in India, even if this should last for fifteen years.
('95', 312, 4, 7, 660591) India is the source of the deepest and strongest spiritual insight and culture in the world.
('95', 312, 4, 8, 660684) It is also the most enduring.
('95', 312, 4, 9, 660714) Despite the grave harm that has been done to Hindu culture by the modern loss of religion and contact with the West which so fully embodies that secularism, Hindu culture still stands supreme.
('95', 312, 5, 10, 660907) More than anyone else, you represent that Hindu culture, and the continuance of your life is of great importance to all the world.
('95', 312, 5, 11, 661038) Even though for a time the number of those who agree with you and truly follow the road of ahimsa may shrink to only a handful, the very smallness makes possible an enhancement of quality and spiritual power.
('95', 312, 5, 12, 661247) We may not tell God that if violence (the folly men) does not stop within a certain time that fits our hopes, we will stop doing our utmost including living as long as we can in order to our utmost.
('95', 312, 5, 13, 661446) I only dare say this to you because I want you so much to stay with us.
('95', 312, 5, 14, 661518) The dispatch from which Mr. Gregg quotes is substantially correct.
('95', 312, 5, 15, 661585) The loss of hope arises from my knowledge that I have not attained sufficient detachment and control over my temper and emotions which entitle one to entertain the hope.
('95', 312, 5, 16, 661755) One day I found to my cost that I had not attained the required detachment.
('95', 312, 5, 17, 661831) No one has the right to live at all unless it is a life of service.
('95', 312, 5, 18, 661899) And a man without detachment in terms of the Gita cannot render full service.
('95', 312, 5, 19, 661977) A faithful confession of one’s failings is good for the soul.
('95', 312, 5, 20, 662039) It enables one the better to get rid of those failings.
('95', 312, 5, 21, 662095) Let the readers of the Harijan know that I am making every effort to get out of them so that I can regain the lost hope.
('95', 312, 5, 22, 662216) In this connection I should also repeat that the hope is open to every one who dedicates himself to the service of his fellowmen.
('95', 312, 5, 23, 662346) Nor need it be laughed out as an idle dream.
('95', 312, 5, 24, 662391) That it may not be realized in me and many fellow aspirants should be no
('95', 312, 6, 25, 662464) 1 Only extracts from the letter are reproduced here.
('95', 313, 0, 1, 662517) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 313, 1, 2, 662559) proof of its futility.
('95', 313, 1, 3, 662582) The statement that I find no place for myself in a society that bases itself on violence had nothing to do with the reported loss of hope.
('95', 313, 1, 4, 662721) I deliberately use the adjective ‘reported’ for I do not want to harbour the thought of hopelessness.
('95', 313, 1, 5, 662823) What was true when the report was made, need not be and is not true in an equal measure today.
('95', 313, 1, 6, 662918) It must be clear that there can be no place for a man of peace in a society full of strife.
('95', 313, 1, 7, 663010) Yet he may live the full span of 125 years and may hope by ceaseless striving to make a place for himself.
('95', 313, 1, 8, 663117) That is exactly the meaning of my second statement and no more.
('95', 313, 1, 9, 663181) I am in that society, though not of it.
('95', 313, 1, 10, 663221) The statement registers my protest.
('95', 313, 1, 11, 663257) Has the non violent effort of the past 30 years come to naught?
('95', 313, 1, 12, 663321) I have already argued out the position in my speeches reported in these columns.
('95', 313, 1, 13, 663402) It is to be hoped that the violence has not penetrated India’s villages.
('95', 313, 1, 14, 663475) Be that as it may, I wholly endorse Mr. Gregg’s warning that ‘‘we may not tell God that if violence (the folly of men) does not stop within a certain time that fits our hopes, we will stop doing our utmost including living as long as we can.’’ I very much fear that the dispatch in question tore the sentences out of their context and evoked the doubts expressed by Mr. Gregg.
('95', 313, 1, 15, 663852) I hope I am incapable of judging God.

('95', 313, 4, 18, 663934) 291. LETTER TO H. GREENFIELD
('95', 313, 5, 19, 663963) BHANGI COLONY, NEW DELHI, June 22, 1947
('95', 313, 6, 20, 664003) DEAR MR. GREENFIELD 1, I have just finished reading your very interesting monograph on salt.
('95', 313, 6, 21, 664096) If it has not been sent for printing and if it still admits of improv ement, I would suggest that the tenth chapter on future development should be expanded so as to place at the disposal of the public cheap and effective methods of producing salt in small quantities.
('95', 313, 7, 22, 664365) 1 Member.
('95', 313, 7, 23, 664375) Central Board of Revenue
('95', 314, 0, 1, 664400) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 315
('95', 314, 1, 2, 664441) You have suggested a Salt Board.
('95', 314, 1, 3, 664474) The idea seems to be attractive but I do not at all like the suggestion about controlling production and distribution through selective licences.
('95', 314, 1, 4, 664620) I am studying the present movement of salt and so far as I know it is very unsatisfactory.
('95', 314, 1, 5, 664711) Special contractors are said to produce salt and control its price also.
('95', 314, 1, 6, 664784) My information may be inaccurate, even faulty.
('95', 314, 1, 7, 664831) If it is neither inaccurate nor faulty the manner is a great handicap.
('95', 314, 1, 8, 664902) I abide by the suggestion made to you at one of our pleasant talks that salt should be manufactured by Government or under its supervision but without monopoly.
('95', 314, 1, 9, 665063) Whoever wishes may compete with the Govern ment at his own risk.
('95', 314, 1, 10, 665128) By so doing the best quality of salt would be produced at the cheapest rate.
('95', 314, 1, 11, 665205) If this is done with care, attention and faithfulness, India will be able to produce all the salt required for the consumption of men and animals and for purposes of curing and industry.
('95', 314, 2, 12, 665392) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('95', 316, 1, 2, 669389) 293. TALK WITH WOMEN WORKERS 1
('95', 316, 2, 3, 669420) NEW DELHI, June 22, 1947 Frankly speaking we are not going to make any progress till we have patriotism, sincerity and honesty.
('95', 316, 2, 4, 669548) We are not even fully independent yet and I have been receiving complaints that some so called eminent leaders of India are making money through their sons, that nepotism is on the increase as also is corru ption and that I should do something about it.
('95', 316, 2, 5, 669802) If it is true all one can say is that we have reached the limit of our misfortune.
('95', 316, 2, 6, 669885) I am an old man.
('95', 316, 2, 7, 669902) Why should I be afraid of anything?
('95', 316, 2, 8, 669938) How long can this kind of administration go on?
('95', 316, 2, 9, 669986) The fact is that we have raised our standard of living so much that we are compelled to resort to dishonest ways.
('95', 316, 2, 10, 670100) We are human beings.
('95', 316, 2, 11, 670121) Since God has granted us human form we should show at least a modicum of honesty in our conduct.
('95', 316, 2, 12, 670218) We are betraying our way of life and that is why we are suffering.
('95', 316, 2, 13, 670285) I have a few letters describing some of the dishonest means Congressmen are resorting to in order to further their selfish interest.
('95', 316, 2, 14, 670418) This has made me unhappy.
('95', 316, 2, 15, 670444) I must also confess that at present I am not in a position to say anything to anyone.
('95', 316, 2, 16, 670530) For haven’t I grown too old and therefore has not my mind too atrophied?
('95', 316, 2, 17, 670603) However, bear in mind that all this is not going to go on for very long.
('95', 316, 2, 18, 670676) I do not want to live to see all this.
('95', 316, 2, 19, 670715) But if they go on deceiving us there will be such a tremendous upheaval that the golden history of our cherished freedom, won without shedding a drop of blood, will be tarnished.
('95', 316, 2, 20, 670894) A mother, having brought forth a child, selflessly devotes herself to his care till he grows up and becomes independent.
('95', 316, 2, 21, 671015) Even after the children are grown up her constant desire is to make herself one with them.
('95', 316, 2, 22, 671106) Unless we have the same feeling and devotion for our motherland, many countries will be lying in wait to crush us down.
('95', 316, 2, 23, 671226) You sisters can do much if you are disposed to.
('95', 316, 2, 24, 671274) But to my grief and shame I have to say that women today have given themselves up to luxurious ways of living.
('95', 316, 2, 25, 671385) They take pride in going to the clubs, wearing foreign dresses and talking in English with their own countrymen.
('95', 316, 2, 26, 671498) I can understand one’s talking in English with those who do not know our language.

('95', 324, 1, 2, 683522) 304. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 324, 2, 3, 683552) NEW DELHI, June 23, 1947 The proposed partition of India and of the provinces is going to be a test for us.
('95', 324, 2, 4, 683660) Today’s newspapers say that the Bill for the partition of India will be introduced in Parliament with much ceremony and India which has so far been one nation will now become two nations.
('95', 324, 2, 5, 683848) It is a sad occasion and calls for no celebrations.
('95', 324, 2, 6, 683900) We cherish the hope that although we are separating we are separating as brothers belong ing to the same family and that we shall remain friends nevertheless.
('95', 324, 2, 7, 684059) If what the newspapers say is true Britain intends to divide us into two nations and that with fanfare.
('95', 324, 2, 8, 684163) Will this be their parting shot?
('95', 324, 2, 9, 684196) I hope not.
('95', 324, 2, 10, 684208) But if the larger part of the country, that is the Indian Union, does its duty, they will be checkmated by their own move.
('95', 324, 2, 11, 684331) We cannot now escape division however much we may dislike it.
('95', 324, 2, 12, 684393) But a higher dharma demands that we should pursue straight path and still consider ourselves one nation refusingto treat the Muslim minority as outsiders.
('95', 324, 2, 13, 684548) India is as much their country as it is ours.
('95', 324, 2, 14, 684594) It means, clearly, that we have to bring about revolutionary changes in Hinduism.
('95', 324, 2, 15, 684676) We are marred with the blot of untouchability.
('95', 324, 2, 16, 684723) It certainly is our weakness.
('95', 324, 2, 17, 684753) One reads that Muslim League leaders have been holding out the bait of separate electorates for the untouch ables in Pakistan.
('95', 324, 2, 18, 684880) Is this an invitation to them to join Pakistan and Islam?
('95', 324, 2, 19, 684938) I do not wish to comment on the recent reports of forcible conversions.
('95', 324, 2, 20, 685010) I have myself heard things from untouchable brethren.
('95', 324, 2, 21, 685064) I am full of fears about what is going to happen.
('95', 324, 2, 22, 685114) There is only one way of getting rid of this fear and it is that the spectre of untouchability should be exorcised.
('95', 324, 2, 23, 685230) Let there be no untouchables in India.
('95', 324, 2, 24, 685269) Let all Hindus be one.
('95', 324, 2, 25, 685292) Let there be no high and low.
('95', 324, 2, 26, 685322) Let us show special consideration for those poor sections, such as untouchables and the adivasis, whom we have so far ignored.
('95', 324, 2, 27, 685449) Let us educate them, see to their proper living.
('95', 324, 2, 28, 685498) All should be listed alike in the voters’ roll.
('95', 324, 2, 29, 685546) The present condition should be changed.
('95', 324, 2, 30, 685587) It should become vastly better.
('95', 324, 2, 31, 685619) Will Hinduism rise to such heights or will it cling to false values, copy other in their evil ways and thus commit suicide?
('95', 324, 2, 32, 685743) That is the question before us.

('95', 327, 4, 32, 690142) NEW DELHI, June 24, 1947
('95', 327, 5, 33, 690167) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, This bhajan dwells on the piteous plight of Rama in the story.
('95', 327, 5, 34, 690252) Here is Rama, about to be crowned but ordered to go to the forest as an exile!
('95', 327, 5, 35, 690331) Can there be anything more pitiable?
('95', 327, 5, 36, 690368) Something similar is now happening before our eyes.
('95', 327, 5, 37, 690420) There is on the one hand rejoicing
('95', 328, 0, 1, 690455) VOL. 95: 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY, 1947 329
('95', 328, 1, 2, 690496) everywhere in the world at the British Government’s decision to grant Dominion Status to India.
('95', 328, 1, 3, 690592) On the other hand we are engaged in a fratricidal strife in the name of defending religion.
('95', 328, 1, 4, 690684) I receive many letters every day attacking me.
('95', 328, 1, 5, 690731) Some say I have destroyed the Hindus, some others that I have been appeasing the Muslims.
('95', 328, 1, 6, 690821) They make no impression on me.
('95', 328, 1, 7, 690852) I seek to appeal to no one except God, for we are all His creatures, His servants.
('95', 328, 1, 8, 690935) And why should I allow myself to be annoyed by these letters?
('95', 328, 1, 9, 690997) How have I offended?
('95', 328, 1, 10, 691018) I only say that no one can protect his religion by doing sinful things or by committing atrocities on others.
('95', 328, 1, 11, 691128) This applies to Hindus and Muslims alike.
('95', 328, 1, 12, 691170) That Pakistan is a bad thing, I agree.
('95', 328, 1, 13, 691209) What is there to rejoice over it?
('95', 328, 1, 14, 691243) Our country has been divided.
('95', 328, 1, 15, 691273) What is there in it to celebrate?
('95', 328, 1, 16, 691307) For the last sixty years, since I was a schoolboy, I have believed that all Indians, be they Hindus, Muslims, Parsis or Christians, are brothers.
('95', 328, 1, 17, 691453) Now that our land has been divided, does it mean that we should divide our hearts?
('95', 328, 1, 18, 691536) How can the people of a country become two peoples?
('95', 328, 1, 19, 691588) India can have only one people.
('95', 328, 1, 20, 691620) When I say this they abuse me.
('95', 328, 1, 21, 691651) Shall I listen to them and become a murderer?
('95', 328, 1, 22, 691697) By so doing I shall only be harming myself.
('95', 328, 1, 23, 691741) One is one’s own foe as well as one’s own friend.
('95', 328, 1, 24, 691791) Hindus alone can destroy the Hindus and no one else.
('95', 328, 1, 25, 691844) Today flames are raging everywhere.
('95', 328, 1, 26, 691880) Hinduism will be saved only if we can save ourselves from these flames.
('95', 328, 1, 27, 691952) My physical powers are waning.
('95', 328, 1, 28, 691983) I am no longer strong enough to put with this heat.
('95', 328, 1, 29, 692035) It is a permanent law that truth ever triumphs and falsehood perishes.

('95', 344, 2, 3, 720264) NEW DELHI, June 27, 1947 I do not know why but I cannot swallow the idea that mechanization should be stepped up in India and that the country should find happiness through it.
('95', 344, 2, 4, 720441) Either I am in error or I am not able to make myself understood.
('95', 344, 2, 5, 720506) Have you given thought to the possible consequences of using tractors and pumping machines to water the fields and trucks instead of carts for transport of goods?
('95', 344, 2, 6, 720669) How many farmers will become unemployed, how many bullocks will become idle?
('95', 344, 2, 7, 720746) Moreover, I feel that in the long run the land will lose its fertility if it is ploughed with machines and tractors.
('95', 344, 2, 8, 720863) People will stop keeping cattle and we shall have to import fertilizers.
('95', 344, 2, 9, 720936) Even the small children get work if a peasant has a plough in his own house and tills his land himself.
('95', 344, 2, 10, 721040) For example one person can work on the kos 1, another channels the water to the fields, one can plough while another does the weeding.
('95', 344, 2, 11, 721175) In this way each will live on the labour of each.
('95', 344, 2, 12, 721225) How natural and happy village life is, while life dependent on machinery is unhappy and brings unemployment.
('95', 344, 2, 13, 721334) Yes, machinery has a place but it has been misused.
('95', 344, 2, 14, 721386) So far we had been fighting against the British in order to give the village industries their due place.
('95', 344, 2, 15, 721491) We should be careful that the same thing is not repeated.

('95', 348, 1, 23, 731496) (d) Already there has been a movement to win over to the Muslim side the so called scheduled classes and the so called aboriginal races.

('95', 352, 5, 11, 737929) 337. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 352, 6, 12, 737959) NEW DELHI, June 28, 1947
('95', 352, 7, 13, 737984) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, What I am going to tell you today will be something very special.
('95', 352, 7, 14, 738072) I hope you will hear me with attention and try to digest what I say.
('95', 352, 7, 15, 738141) When someone does something good he makes the whole world partake of the good.
('95', 352, 7, 16, 738220) When someone does something bad, though he cannot make the world share his action he can certainly cause harm.
('95', 352, 7, 17, 738331) The Constituent Assembly is discussing the rights of the citizen.
('95', 352, 7, 18, 738397) That is to say they are deliberating on what the fundamental rights should be.
('95', 352, 7, 19, 738476) As a matter of fact the proper question is not what the rights of a citizen are, but rather what constitutes the duties of a citizen.
('95', 352, 7, 20, 738610) Fun damental rights can only be those rights the exercise of which is not only in the interest of the citizen but that of the whole world.
('95', 352, 7, 21, 738749) Today everyone wants to know what his rights are, but if a man learns to discharge his duties right from childhood and studies the sacred books of his faith he automatically exercises his rights too.
('95', 352, 7, 22, 738949) I learnt my duties on my mother’s lap.
('95', 352, 7, 23, 738988) She was an unlettered village woman.
('95', 352, 7, 24, 739025) She was unable even to sign her name.
('95', 352, 7, 25, 739063) Nobody in those days thought of learning to read and write by employing tutors.
('95', 352, 7, 26, 739143) I am telling you of
('95', 352, 8, 27, 739163) 1 Wife of Chimanlal N. Shah 2 Vide “Walls of Protection”, 15 6 19 74 3 Kishorelal G. Mashruwala 4 Addressee’s niece
('95', 353, 0, 1, 739279) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 353, 1, 2, 739321) things seventy years ago.
('95', 353, 1, 3, 739347) My father was a Diwan, but at that time a Diwan did not have to be particularly well versed in English.
('95', 353, 1, 4, 739451) He dressed himself in an angarkha and wore village style shoes.
('95', 353, 1, 5, 739515) He did not even know what trousers were.
('95', 353, 1, 6, 739556) My mother taught me to repeat Ramanama.
('95', 353, 1, 7, 739596) She knew my dharma.
('95', 353, 1, 8, 739616) Thus if from childhood we learn what our dharma is and try to follow it our rights look after them selves.
('95', 353, 1, 9, 739723) I could live only on condition that I drank the milk that my mother gave me.
('95', 353, 1, 10, 739800) If I had shirked the obligation to drink milk I would have forfeited my right to live.
('95', 353, 1, 11, 739887) The beauty of it is that the very performance of a duty secures us our right.
('95', 353, 1, 12, 739965) Rights cannot be divorced from duties.
('95', 353, 1, 13, 740004) This is how satyagraha was born, for I was always striving to decide what my duty was.
('95', 353, 1, 14, 740091) Today we notice a strange phenomenon.
('95', 353, 1, 15, 740129) He who is a ruler for a moment gets it into his head that has been created by God solely to rule over people, that he has the right to hang some, to imprison others and to fine some others.
('95', 353, 1, 16, 740319) He wants that all the duties should be discharged by the people.
('95', 353, 1, 17, 740384) He says he has derived his right to rule from God.
('95', 353, 1, 18, 740435) Industrial workers and industrial magnates are demanding their respective rights.
('95', 353, 1, 19, 740517) The zamindar insists on his rights, the peasant on his.
('95', 353, 1, 20, 740573) But there are no such two classes here that one of them should exercise only rights and the other discharge only duties.
('95', 353, 1, 21, 740694) If a ruler shirks his duties while the people do theirs then the people become the ruler.
('95', 353, 1, 22, 740784) If the ruler does his duty and considers himself the trustee of his people he will survive.
('95', 353, 1, 23, 740876) But if he becomes authoritarian he cannot survive in this age.
('95', 353, 1, 24, 740939) Till now we have been sunk in darkness.

('95', 353, 1, 27, 741127) But in truth a sovereign is only the first servant of the people.
('95', 353, 1, 28, 741193) It is the duty of the servant to surrender all to the master and then live on what is left over.
('95', 353, 1, 29, 741290) The people similarly should learn to do their duty.
('95', 353, 1, 30, 741342) They are in millions.
('95', 353, 1, 31, 741364) If they are so disposed they can kill the ruler.
('95', 353, 1, 32, 741413) But by so doing they will only harm themselves.
('95', 353, 1, 33, 741461) If we keep our streets clean and well lighted or do something similar we should do it as a duty.
('95', 353, 1, 34, 741558) Every one of us should become a scavenger.
('95', 353, 1, 35, 741601) A man who does not first become a scavenger cannot live, nor has he a right to live and we are all scavengers in some sense or other even if we do not admit it.
('95', 353, 1, 36, 741762) If the people pay taxes it is not so as to fill the coffers of the ruler but because without that the administration cannot function.
('95', 353, 1, 37, 741896) The same thing applies to mill workers and mill owners.

('95', 358, 4, 13, 751196) 344. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('95', 358, 5, 14, 751226) NEW DELHI, June 29, 1947
('95', 358, 6, 15, 751251) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('95', 358, 7, 16, 751273) Yesterday I talked to you about duty.
('95', 358, 7, 17, 751311) However I was not able to say all that I had intended to say.
('95', 358, 7, 18, 751373) Whenever a person goes anywhere certain duties come to devolve on him.
('95', 358, 7, 19, 751444) The man who neglects his duty and cares only to safeguard his rights does not know that rights that do not spring from duties done cannot be safeguarded.
('95', 358, 7, 20, 751598) This applies also to the Hindu Muslim relations.
('95', 358, 7, 21, 751647) Whether it is the Hindus living in a place or Muslims or both, they will come to acquire rights if they do their duty.
('95', 358, 7, 22, 751766) Then they do not have to demand rights.
('95', 358, 7, 23, 751806) A child feeds at his mother’s breast because it is his duty to do so.
('95', 358, 7, 24, 751876) And this alone gives him the right to live.
('95', 358, 7, 25, 751920) This is a paramount law and no one can change it.
('95', 358, 7, 26, 751970) If Hindus consider Muslims their brothers and treat them well, Muslims too will return friendship for friendship.
('95', 358, 7, 27, 752084) Take a village for example.
('95', 358, 7, 28, 752112) If there are in it five hundred Hindus and five Muslims, then the five hundred Hindus come to have certain obligations
('95', 358, 8, 29, 752231) 1 Leader of the Congress party in the Punjab Assembly
('95', 359, 0, 1, 752285) 360 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 359, 1, 2, 752327) towards the five Muslims which ipso facto gives Hindus certain rights.
('95', 359, 1, 3, 752398) In their arrogance they should not think that they can crush the Muslims and kill them for it cannot be anyone’s right to kill.
('95', 359, 1, 4, 752526) There is no bravery in killing.
('95', 359, 1, 5, 752558) It is cowardice and a disgrace.
('95', 359, 1, 6, 752590) The duty of the Hindus is to share with the Muslims in their joys and sorrows even if they wear beards and face towards the West during namaaz.
('95', 359, 1, 7, 752734) They should see whether they are getting enough food and water and whether their other needs are being satisfied.
('95', 359, 1, 8, 752848) When the five hundred Hindus do their duty, then they earn the right to expect that the five Muslims also would do theirs.
('95', 359, 1, 9, 752971) If the village catches fire and the Muslims think that they should let it burn and do everything to see that it spreads, then they will not be doing their duty.
('95', 359, 1, 10, 753132) Fires in villages are a common occurrence.
('95', 359, 1, 11, 753175) If someone lights a bidi and throws away the burning match stick and it comes into contact with a little dried grass or wisp of cotton, a fire starts.
('95', 359, 1, 12, 753326) And since villages mostly have thatched roofs just a little wind can make the fire consume the whole village.
('95', 359, 1, 13, 753436) But as a matter of course in such an eventuality the five Muslims will also want to extinguish the fire and will set about bringing pails of water for the purpose.
('95', 359, 1, 14, 753600) By thus doing their duty they automatically acquire rights.
('95', 359, 1, 15, 753660) Today we do not do our duty.
('95', 359, 1, 16, 753689) The work goes on because God has so made the world that its progress does not stop.

('95', 359, 1, 21, 754132) I shall not do so.
('95', 359, 1, 22, 754151) I shall confine him in a room and stop others from treating him roughly.
('95', 359, 1, 23, 754224) This is the human way.
('95', 359, 1, 24, 754247) Similarly if the Muslims in question do not want to behave in a friendly manner and keep on say ing that they are a separate nation, that though they are only five, they can summon five crores of Muslims from outside, the Hindus should not let themselves be frightened by such a threat.
('95', 359, 1, 25, 754534) They should tell the Mus lims outside that they want to be friends with the five Muslims, but that they don’t reciprocate.
('95', 359, 1, 26, 754657) That if they want to help them it is their affair, but the Hindus would not be frightened or subdued by force.
('95', 359, 1, 27, 754768) The world will understand that the five hundred Hindus are good people and want to do their duty.
('95', 359, 1, 28, 754866) The same thing applies to a village where there are five hundred Muslims and only five Hindus.
('95', 359, 1, 29, 754961) There are many such villages in Pakistan.
('95', 359, 1, 30, 755003) Some people from the Jhelam area had been to see me.
('95', 360, 0, 1, 755056) VOL. 95 : 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY 1947 361

('95', 360, 1, 3, 755159) I told them that if the Muslims there were good people, could exercise self control in doing their duty, then they would have nothing to fear.
('95', 360, 1, 4, 755302) But if the few Hindus there were wicked, then even if Hindus from all over India went to help them nothing would be gained.

('95', 368, 1, 2, 768734) 357. A LETTER June 30, 1947 I was pained to read about your illness.
('95', 368, 1, 3, 768803) He who wishes to serve must not fall ill.
('95', 368, 1, 4, 768845) And if one does not want to fall ill, then surely one must not transgress nature’s laws!
('95', 368, 1, 5, 768934) If you had made proper use of nature’s gifts, namely, air, sun, earth, water, food and rest and had at the same time kept repeating Ramanama, you would have escaped such serious illness.
('95', 368, 1, 6, 769121) Drink plenty of water, apply mud packs, take baths and live only on fruit juice.
('95', 368, 1, 7, 769202) We look upon a fruit diet as a costly diet, but this is a great error.
('95', 368, 1, 8, 769273) The truth is that in our lethargy we do not take the necessary trouble to grow vegetables and fruits.
('95', 368, 1, 9, 769375) If we shed our lethargy and ignorance, we shall find this seemingly costly diet quite inexpensive and be able to maintain perfect health.
('95', 368, 1, 10, 769513) In the morning, you should take sun bath with the whole body, except the head, completely uncovered.
('95', 368, 1, 11, 769614) You should also take hip baths in warm and cold water.
('95', 368, 1, 12, 769669) If you do not pass clear stools, take enema.
('95', 368, 1, 13, 769714) And take complete rest.
('95', 368, 1, 14, 769738) The mind also has a great effect on the body.
('95', 368, 1, 15, 769784) Therefore, without tiring yourself read some good books or have them read to you in a spirit of devotion, and shut your eyes and meditate on God.
('95', 368, 1, 16, 769930) I am sure you will get well if you do this much.
('95', 368, 1, 17, 769979) Dictate a letter to me from time to time.
('95', 368, 1, 18, 770021) Avoid the labour of writing yourself.

('95', 375, 6, 11, 781855) 367. A LETTER July 1, 1947 There is a perpetual conflict in man’s heart between the two opposing forces, darkness and light.
('95', 375, 6, 12, 781980) If these did not exist there would be no life.
('95', 375, 6, 13, 782027) I am, therefore, struggling to find light.
('95', 375, 6, 14, 782070) A handful of capitalists are ruling over millions with the help of machines.
('95', 375, 6, 15, 782147) They are impelled solely by self interest and greed.
('95', 375, 6, 16, 782200) I am ready to devote all my energies to ending this economic inequality, but only if I emerge safely from this conflagration.
('95', 375, 6, 17, 782326) Let us take a warning from the damage we have suffered from the present Hindu Muslim conflict in the country and the shameful exhibition of ourselves that we have made before the world.
('95', 375, 6, 18, 782512) If we do not take a similar warning also from the existing economic inequality, we shall suffer the same fate in future that we are doing today.
('95', 375, 6, 19, 782657) I must admit, however, that today I am alone in thinking as I do.
('95', 375, 6, 20, 782723) No one has so far paid any attention to the Harijan men, women and children with whom I am staying these days.
('95', 375, 6, 21, 782834) It remains to be seen how much I can do from here.
('95', 375, 6, 22, 782885) I assume that you take sufficient care of your health.
('95', 375, 6, 23, 782940) ‘If the mind is pure, we have the Ganga flowing by the doorstep.’ Remember, therefore, that health of the body depends upon that of the mind.
('95', 375, 6, 24, 783082) [From Gujarati]
('95', 375, 7, 25, 783098) Bihar Pachhi Dilhi, p.

('95', 377, 2, 3, 784609) NEW DELHI, July 1, 1947
('95', 377, 3, 4, 784633) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, You will have understood the bhajan that has been sung.
('95', 377, 3, 5, 784711) It was composed by Tukdoji Maharaj of the Central Provinces.
('95', 377, 3, 6, 784772) Its language is Hindustani—not the Hindustani crammed with Arabic and Persian words but the Hindustani of Delhi.
('95', 377, 3, 7, 784885) It has beauty and sweetness.
('95', 377, 3, 8, 784914) It says that Rama is accessible to one who has suffered loss of home and property, the loss of friends and companions or suffers from bodily disease.
('95', 377, 3, 9, 785064) If a person in spite of such misfortune does not leave Rama then he finds Rama.
('95', 377, 3, 10, 785144) A friend complains that I have been saying at prayer meetings that the division of India has somehow to be undone.
('95', 377, 3, 11, 785259) But I have never said this.
('95', 377, 3, 12, 785287) When something has been agreed upon between the Congress and the League and the country has been divided, what can be gained by opposing it?
('95', 377, 3, 13, 785428) After all the hearts have not been divided.
('95', 377, 3, 14, 785472) The Congress has accepted Pakistan and we must let it go at that.
('95', 377, 3, 15, 785538) A Sikh youth asks me what I, claiming to love the Sikhs, am doing to prove it.
('95', 377, 3, 16, 785617) Hindus and Muslims have both gained something.
('95', 377, 3, 17, 785664) But what have the Sikhs gained?
('95', 377, 3, 18, 785696) I can only say that if the Punjab has been divided I can do nothing about it.
('95', 377, 3, 19, 785774) I have not the power in my hands.
('95', 377, 3, 20, 785808) To me there is no difference between Sikhism and Hinduism.
('95', 377, 3, 21, 785867) I have read the Granth Saheb.
('95', 377, 3, 22, 785897) What it contains is also contained in the Vedic dharma.
('95', 377, 3, 23, 785953) But today they are treated as a separate community.
('95', 377, 3, 24, 786005) It is a small community but well known for its valour.
('95', 377, 3, 25, 786060) I had visits from two friends who have settled in Canada.
('95', 377, 3, 26, 786118) They say Canada has a large number of Sikhs and they are doing good work there.
('95', 377, 3, 27, 786198) There are Sikhs also in Africa.
('95', 377, 3, 28, 786230) One finds Sikhs everywhere one goes.
('95', 377, 3, 29, 786267) They are farmers, engineers, railway mechanics, motor car drivers.
('95', 377, 3, 30, 786334) Today the Sikhs live in great material comfort.
('95', 377, 3, 31, 786382) I had today a wire from the Muslim League at Mathura.
('95', 377, 3, 32, 786436) They say that the Hindus there are ill treating them.
('95', 377, 3, 33, 786490) I do not know how far this is true.
('95', 377, 3, 34, 786526) But if it is true it is not good.
('95', 377, 3, 35, 786560) We should not display the cruelty of numbers.
('95', 377, 3, 36, 786606) The arrogance that comes from the strength of numbers can only destroy us.
('95', 377, 3, 37, 786681) You must be eager to know the result of my meeting with the Viceroy today.

('95', 384, 2, 3, 797914) DELHI, July 2, 1947 If you want to hear the few things that I have come to tell you please maintain silence.
('95', 384, 2, 4, 798023) Yesterday your Vice President came and invited me to this conference.
('95', 384, 2, 5, 798093) I had not known till then that Jayaprakash was the President of the conference.
('95', 384, 2, 6, 798173) When people persisted I was in a fix.
('95', 384, 2, 7, 798211) It would not be right to refuse.
('95', 384, 2, 8, 798244) Drawn by your love, I was forced to come.
('95', 384, 2, 9, 798286) The police tie us up in iron chains, but the bond of love, in the words of Mirabai, though fragile and tenuous, is stronger than any iron chain.
('95', 384, 2, 10, 798431) And drawn by this bond I came here punctually at a quarter past eight.
('95', 384, 2, 11, 798502) Here I shall speak out a few things.
('95', 384, 2, 12, 798539) It has become a fashion these days to call oneself a socialist.
('95', 384, 2, 13, 798603) It is a mistaken notion that one can serve only if one carries a label of some ‘ism’.
('95', 384, 2, 14, 798689) I have been studying the question since the time when Jayaprakash perhaps had not even been born.
('95', 384, 2, 15, 798787) Some fifty years ago when I used to practise law in South Africa there were many people there who called themselves socialists but in fact they were less socialist than I was.
('95', 384, 2, 16, 798963) I used to work among the coolies.
('95', 384, 2, 17, 798997) I had made this work my life’s mission and I lived as the coolies lived.
('95', 384, 2, 18, 799070) I have always considered myself a servant of the workers and peasants but I have never found it necessary to call myself a socialist.
('95', 384, 2, 19, 799204) My socialism is of a different kind.
('95', 384, 2, 20, 799241) Even if everyone forsakes me I shall not be worried.
('95', 384, 2, 21, 799294) I am your friend and, therefore, I tell you that if a cripple cannot obtain something he needs we should ourselves give up that something.
('95', 384, 2, 22, 799433) I shall first watch the cripple’s life and his food and only then shall I think of doing something for myself.
('95', 384, 2, 23, 799544) This is my socialism.
('95', 384, 2, 24, 799566) If you want to bring about this kind of socialism, then I shall be the first to come forward to help.
('95', 384, 2, 25, 799668) It is my firm belief that even a king can become a socialist by being a servant of his people.
('95', 384, 2, 26, 799763) If we want to make the king as well as the people socialist, how shall we set about it?
('95', 384, 2, 27, 799851) We can convert others to socialism by setting an example ourselves.

('95', 384, 2, 30, 800042) My method is to make the king a socialist through love.
('95', 384, 2, 31, 800098) It is heinous to kill.

('95', 390, 1, 7, 810803) In ancient times the gurus always lived in the forests and the children of both kings and paupers had to go there for study.

('95', 390, 1, 9, 811000) There were therefore no bickerings.
('95', 390, 1, 10, 811036) But we in our wisdom improved upon this.
('95', 390, 1, 11, 811077) to save the children the arduous journey into the forest we established institutions with all the conveniences, thus making ourselves unhappy rather that happy and squandering public money.
('95', 390, 1, 12, 811267) In Kathiawad there was a very good institution by the name of Dakshinamurti, but it was not self supporting and ultimately it became a burden.
('95', 390, 1, 13, 811410) That was owing to quarrels among the workers.
('95', 390, 1, 14, 811456) I do not understand why the educational institutions cannot become self supporting.

('95', 390, 1, 17, 811655) In some way they are guilty of some lapse… 1 A similar incident concerning… had once come before me.

('95', 391, 3, 4, 812217) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, You have heard the bhajan.

('95', 391, 3, 6, 812351) We are in the world of God and we do not know God.
('95', 391, 3, 7, 812402) It is our ill luck, for God is always with us.
