('95', 391, 3, 14, 812781) The division of India does not change the map of India.
('95', 391, 3, 15, 812837) It remains as it was.
('95', 391, 3, 16, 812859) A friend writes to me that the Brahmins in India are like a rock in sea.
('95', 391, 3, 17, 812932) Their number is infinitesimal.
('95', 391, 3, 18, 812963) I am in a minority if I am all by myself.
('95', 391, 3, 19, 813005) The rock is in a minority if it stands aloof from the sea.
('95', 391, 3, 20, 813064) Then it shrivels up.
('95', 391, 3, 21, 813085) But when it is in the sea it is a part of the sea.
('95', 391, 3, 22, 813136) How can then the Brahmins be a minority in the sea that is the Hindu community.
('95', 391, 3, 23, 813216) There was a time when only Brahmin boys went to school.
('95', 391, 3, 24, 813272) Since they have been given to learning from the very beginning, they also learnt wherever there was something new to be learnt.
('95', 391, 3, 25, 813400) Today of course even those who are not Brahmins get education.
('95', 391, 3, 26, 813463) Why should then the Brahmins complain about their sons not getting admission?
('95', 391, 3, 27, 813541) I have been talking to you about rights.
('95', 391, 3, 28, 813582) There is no such thing as a right.
('95', 391, 3, 29, 813617) If a Brahmin claims education as a matter of right, I may ask him how he came to acquire the right.
('95', 391, 3, 30, 813717) I do not believe in birthright.
('95', 391, 3, 31, 813749) Rights are a result of the duties done.
('95', 391, 3, 32, 813789) You will agree that a sinner has the right to reap the harvest of his sins.
('95', 391, 3, 33, 813865) I say that one who does noble deeds has a right to the fruits of those deeds.
('95', 391, 3, 34, 813943) If someone asks me what the rights of the Brahmin are I shall say it is his right to know the Brahman.
('95', 391, 3, 35, 814046) A Brahmin has only two duties—to know the science of the Brahman and to teach it to others.

('95', 394, 5, 13, 818592) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Some people ask me if what has happened and what is hap pening and the Dominion Status that we are about to get will lead to Ramarajya.
('95', 394, 5, 14, 818750) Those who put the question are usually sarcastic and I have to admit that I cannot say that all this will lead to Ramarajya.
('95', 394, 5, 15, 818875) All the signs I see are against it.
('95', 394, 5, 16, 818911) The country has been divided and there will be two Dominions and, if they are hostile to each other, how can we expect the estab lishment of Ramarajya?
('95', 394, 5, 17, 819063) Of course Dominion Status does not imply subservience to the British.
('95', 394, 5, 18, 819133) It is as good as independence.
('95', 394, 5, 19, 819164) But the other Dominions in the British Commonwealth are more or less of the same race.
('95', 394, 5, 20, 819251) Since India is an Asian country, how can it remain a Dominion?
('95', 394, 5, 21, 819314) If all the countries of the world were to become such Dominions, that would be a different matter and then Ramarajya could be brought about.
('95', 394, 5, 22, 819455) But what has come about cannot lead to Ramarajya or the Kingdom of God.
('95', 394, 5, 23, 819527) The British Government had originally intended to transfer power to Indian hands by June 30, 1948. But now they have decided that the sooner they get out the better it would be.
('95', 394, 5, 24, 819705) But how can they do that?
('95', 394, 5, 25, 819731) So they came to the conclusion that if Dominion Status were granted to the divided India there would be no risks because then they would still have links with us.
('95', 394, 5, 26, 819894) I do not want India to be a frog in the well, unaware of what happens outside the well.
('95', 394, 5, 27, 819982) Jawaharlal and other leaders have said that we will not be hostile to any country.

('95', 395, 1, 5, 820377) Some countries today describe themselves as democratic but of course one does not become a democrat by simply saying so.
('95', 395, 1, 6, 820498) What is the need for an army where there is rule by the people?

('95', 395, 2, 17, 821382) It should therefore be described not as ahimsa but as passive resistance.
('95', 395, 2, 18, 821456) But the ahimsa I advocated was not the ahimsa of the weak while passive resistance is only for the weak.
('95', 395, 2, 19, 821561) Then passive resistance is a preparation for active and armed resistance.

('95', 395, 3, 21, 821733) Our passive resistance has not been a complete failure.
('95', 395, 3, 22, 821789) We have all but won our freedom.
('95', 395, 3, 23, 821822) The violence we see today is the violence of cowards.
('95', 395, 3, 24, 821876) There is also such a thing as the violence of the brave.
('95', 395, 3, 25, 821933) If four or five men enter into a fight and die by the sword, there is violence in it but it is the violence of the brave.
('95', 395, 3, 26, 822055) But when ten thousand armed men attack a village of unarmed people and slaughter them along with their wives and children it is the violence of cowards.
('95', 395, 3, 27, 822208) America unleashed its atom bomb over Japan.
('95', 395, 3, 28, 822252) That was the violence of the cowards.
('95', 395, 3, 29, 822290) The non violence of the brave is a thing worth seeing.

('95', 401, 2, 3, 830913) NEW DELHI, July 5, 1947
('95', 401, 3, 4, 830937) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Lady Mountbatten has been to see me today.
('95', 401, 3, 5, 831002) She had no particular business with me.
('95', 401, 3, 6, 831042) I even told her on the telephone not to take the trouble to come and see me.
('95', 401, 3, 7, 831119) But she said that since I had gone and seen them so many times she felt bound to return the visit.
('95', 401, 3, 8, 831218) I pointed out that I only went to see the Viceroy on business.
('95', 401, 3, 9, 831281) But she was firm and she came.
('95', 401, 3, 10, 831312) She has simple ways.
('95', 401, 3, 11, 831333) She came and squatted down as we are squatting here, and inquired after everything.
('95', 401, 3, 12, 831417) She asked how we find it here and listened with interest.
('95', 401, 3, 13, 831475) I told her that I lived here among the sweepers.
('95', 401, 3, 14, 831524) I also told her that I lived in a temple which was clean as it ought to be.
('95', 401, 3, 15, 831600) If she wanted to see the living conditions of the sweepers she should visit their quarters which were nearby.
('95', 401, 3, 16, 831710) She visited the sweepers’ quarters and inspected the condition there with much interest.
('95', 401, 3, 17, 831799) I did not go with her because crowds might have collected.
('95', 401, 3, 18, 831858) Then she went to Harijan Nivas where Harijan boys are given training.
('95', 401, 3, 19, 831928) She was very happy to see it.
('95', 401, 3, 20, 831958) I have today received a letter which I had not intended to deal with here.
('95', 401, 3, 21, 832033) 1 But now I feel that I should not keep it over till tomorrow.

('95', 404, 1, 2, 837843) 406. WHO IS A SOCIALIST?
('95', 404, 2, 3, 837868) Socialism is a beautiful word and so far as I am aware in socialism all the members of society are equal—none low, none high.
('95', 404, 2, 4, 837994) In the individual body the head is not high because it is the top of the body, nor are the soles of the feet low because they touch the earth.
('95', 404, 2, 5, 838137) Even as members of the individual body are equal, so are the members of society.
('95', 404, 2, 6, 838218) That is socialism.
('95', 404, 2, 7, 838237) In it the prince and the peasant, the wealthy and the poor, the employer and the employee are all on the same level.
('95', 404, 2, 8, 838354) In terms of religion there is no duality in socialism.
('95', 404, 2, 9, 838409) It is all unity.
('95', 404, 2, 10, 838426) Looking at society all the world over there is nothing but duality or plurality.
('95', 404, 2, 11, 838507) Unity is conspicuous by its absence.
('95', 404, 2, 12, 838544) This man is high, that one is low, that one is a Hindu, that one a Muslim, third a Christian, fourth a Parsi, fifth a Sikh, sixth a Jew.
('95', 404, 2, 13, 838681) Even among these there are sub divisions.
('95', 404, 2, 14, 838723) In the unity of my conception there is perfect unity in the plurality of designs.
('95', 404, 2, 15, 838805) In order to reach this state we may not look on things philosophically and say that we need not make a move until all are converted to socialism.
('95', 404, 2, 16, 838951) Without changing our life we may go on giving addresses, forming parties and hawk like seize the game when it comes our way.
('95', 404, 2, 17, 839076) This is no socialism.
('95', 404, 2, 18, 839098) The more we treat it as game to be seized, the further it must recede from us.
('95', 404, 2, 19, 839177) Socialism begins with the first convert.
('95', 404, 2, 20, 839218) If there is one such, you can add zeros to the one and the first zero will account for ten and every addition will account for ten times the previous number.
('95', 404, 2, 21, 839376) If, however, the beginner is a zero, in other words, no one makes the beginning, multiplicity of zeros will also produce zero value.
('95', 404, 2, 22, 839509) Time and paper occupied in writing zeros will be so much waste.
('95', 404, 2, 23, 839573) This socialism is as pure as crystal.
('95', 404, 2, 24, 839611) It, therefore, requires crystal like means to achieve it.
('95', 404, 2, 25, 839669) Impure means insult in an impure end.
('95', 404, 2, 26, 839707) Hence the prince and the peasant will not be equalized by cutting off the prince’s head, nor can the process of cutting off equalize the employer and the employee.
('95', 404, 2, 27, 839871) One cannot reach truth by untruth fulness.
('95', 404, 2, 28, 839914) Truthful conduct alone can reach truth.
('95', 404, 2, 29, 839954) Are not non violence and truth twins?
('95', 404, 2, 30, 839992) The answer is an emphatic ‘no’.
('95', 404, 2, 31, 840024) Non violence is embedded in truth and vice versa.
('95', 404, 2, 32, 840074) Hence has it been said that they are

('95', 409, 1, 2, 847426) APPENDIX I
('95', 409, 2, 3, 847437) INTERVIEW WITH LORD MOUNTBATTEN1
('95', 409, 3, 4, 847470) Top Secret Sunday, May 4, 1947, 1605 to 1730 hrs.
('95', 409, 3, 5, 847520) I thanked him for the strong and courageous statement he made rebuking the Press in general, and his own in particular, for their uncalled for attack on me.
('95', 409, 3, 6, 847677) He said that he thought that the Press in India was very immature and had only just been released from censorship and did not realize the harm they were doing by the methods they adopt.
('95', 409, 3, 7, 847863) I outlined the plan which Lord Ismay had taken to London and asked Mr. Gandhi if he agreed that the method I was proposing to adopt, whereby the people of India would decide how they wished power to be transferred, was not a good one.
('95', 409, 3, 8, 848098) He replied that he did not agree that we were leaving the people of India a free choice since we were practically imposing partition on them.
('95', 409, 3, 9, 848240) I then asked him what his plan was and he returned to his original idea and reiterated that if I believed in it firmly I could put it through.
('95', 409, 3, 10, 848383) In fact, he finally invited me to turn over power either to the Muslim League or, if they would not take it, to Congress for the whole of India, and give them immediate Dominion Status and then remain as Governor General for 13 months and then leave them to their own devices.
('95', 409, 3, 11, 848660) When I pointed out that this would lead to a civil war and a blood bath, he replied “not if Mr. Jinnah means what he has signed with me.”
('95', 409, 4, 12, 848798) I told him Jinnah signed in good faith when he thought I was going to give a fair decision and that I did not for one moment suppose the Muslims would not immediately go to war if I attempted to betray them in this matter.
('95', 409, 4, 13, 849021) In any case, I pointed out that H. M. C. would never allow me to hand over a colossal minority like the Muslims into the power of Congress and I much regretted therefore that his plan was not acceptable.
('95', 409, 4, 14, 849225) I did, however, say I would report it to London.

('95', 410, 2, 3, 849535) M. A. JINNAH’S STATEMENT TO THE PRESS1
('95', 410, 3, 4, 849574) May 6, 1947
('95', 410, 4, 5, 849586) We discussed two matters.
('95', 410, 4, 6, 849612) One was the question of division of India into pakistan and Hindustan and Mr. Gandhi does not accept the principle of division.
('95', 410, 4, 7, 849740) He thinks division is not inevitable, whereas, in my opinion, not only is Pakistan inevitable but this is the only practical solution of India’s political problem.
('95', 410, 5, 8, 849904) The second matter which we discussed was a letter 2 which we both have signed jointly appealing to the people to maintain peace and we both have come to the conclusion that we must do our best in our respective spheres to see that that appeal of ours is carried out and we will make every effort for this purpose.
('95', 410, 6, 9, 850218) The Hindu, 7 5 1947
('95', 410, 7, 10, 850238) APPENDIX III BRITISH GOVERNMENT’S STATEMENT 4
('95', 410, 8, 11, 850284) June 3, 1947
('95', 410, 9, 12, 850297) 1. On February 20th, 1947, His Majesty’s Government announced their intention of transferring Power in British India to Indian hands by June 1948. His Majesty’s Government had hoped that it would be possible for the major parties to co operate in the working out of the Cabinet Mission’s Plan of May 16, 1946, and evolve for India a constitution acceptable to all concerned.
('95', 410, 9, 13, 850672) This hope has not been fulfilled.
('95', 410, 10, 14, 850706) 2. The majority of the representatives of the Provinces of Madras, Bombay, the United Provinces, Bihar, Central Provinces and Berar, Assam, Orissa and the North West Frontier Provinces, and the representatives of Delhi, Ajmer Merwara and Coorg have already made progress in the task of evolving a new constitution.
('95', 410, 10, 15, 851021) On the other hand, the Muslim League Party, including in it a majority of the representatives of Bengal, the Punjab and Sind as also the representative of British Baluchistan, has decided not to participate in the Constituent Assembly.
('95', 410, 11, 16, 851257) 3. It has always been the desire of His Majesty’s Government that power
('95', 410, 12, 17, 851329) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 7 5 1947 2Vide “Talk with Sikhs”, 12 4 1947 3 Asked whether there would be any further meeting with M. A. Jinnah Gandhiji replied that no further meeting was likely.
('95', 410, 12, 18, 851529) M. A. Jinnah however declined to answer.
('95', 410, 12, 19, 851570) 4Vide “Speech at Congress Working Committee Meeting”, 2 6 1947
('95', 411, 0, 1, 851633) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 411, 1, 2, 851675) should be transferred in accordance with the wishes of the Indian people themselves.
('95', 411, 1, 3, 851760) This task would have been greatly facilitated if there had been agreement among the Indian political parties.
('95', 411, 1, 4, 851870) In the absence of such agreement, the task of devising a method by which the wishes of the Indian people can be ascertained has devolved upon His Majesty’s Government.
('95', 411, 1, 5, 852038) After full consultation with political leaders in India, His Majesty’s Government have decided to adopt for this purpose the plan set out below.
('95', 411, 1, 6, 852183) His Majesty’s Government wish to make it clear that they have no intention of attempting to frame any ultimate Constitution for India; this is a matter for the Indians themselves.
('95', 411, 1, 7, 852363) Nor is there anything in this plan to preclude negotiations between communities for a united India.
('95', 411, 2, 8, 852463) 4. It is not the intention of His Majesty’s Government to interrupt the work of the existing Constituent Assembly.
('95', 411, 2, 9, 852578) Now that provision is made for certain provinces specified below, His Majesty’s Government trust that, as a consequence of this announcement, the Muslim League representatives of those provinces, a majority of whose representatives are already participating in it, will now take their due share in its labours.
('95', 411, 2, 10, 852889) At the same time it is clear that any constitution framed by this Assembly cannot apply to those parts of the country which are unwilling to accept it.
('95', 411, 2, 11, 853041) His Majesty’s Government are satisfied that the procedure outlined below embodies the best method of ascertaining the wishes of the people of such areas on the issue whether their constitution is to be framed:— (a) in the existing Constituent Assembly; or (b) in a new and separate constituent Assembly consisting of the representatives of those areas which decide not to participate in the existing Constituent Assembly.
('95', 411, 2, 12, 853463) When this has been done, it will be possible to determine the authority or authorities to whom power should be transferred.
('95', 411, 2, 13, 853587) 5. The Provincial Legislative Assemblies of Bengal and the Punjab (excluding the European members) will, therefore, each be asked to meet in two parts, one representing the Muslim majority districts and the rest of the province.
('95', 411, 2, 14, 853816) For the purpose of determining the population of districts, the 1941 census figures will be taken as authoritative.
('95', 411, 2, 15, 853932) The Muslim majority districts in these two provinces are set out in the Appendix to this announcement.
('95', 411, 2, 16, 854035) 6. The members of the two parts of each Legislative Assembly sitting separately will be empowered to vote whether or not the province should be partitioned.
('95', 411, 2, 17, 854192) If a simple majority of either part decides in favour of partition, division will take place and arrangements will be made accordingly.
('95', 411, 2, 18, 854328) 7. Before the question as to the partition is decided, it is desirable that the representatives of each part should know in advance which Constituent Assembly the Province as a whole would join in the event of the two parts subsequently deciding to remain united.
('95', 411, 2, 19, 854592) Therefore, if any member of either Legislative Assembly so demands,
('95', 412, 0, 1, 854660) VOL. 95 : 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY 1947 413
('95', 412, 1, 2, 854701) there shall be held a meeting of all members of the Legislative Assembly (other than European) at which a decision will be taken on the issue as to which Constituent Assembly the Province as a whole would join if it were decided by the two parts to remain united.
('95', 412, 1, 3, 854965) 8. In the event of partition being decided upon, each part of the Legislative Assembly will, on behalf of the areas they represent, decide which of the alternatives in paragraph 4 above to adopt.
('95', 412, 1, 4, 855161) 9. For the immediate purpose of deciding on the issue of partition, the members of the legislative assemblies of Bengal and the Punjab will sit in two parts according to Muslim majority districts (as laid down in the Appendix) and non Muslim majority districts.
('95', 412, 1, 5, 855423) This is only a preliminary step of a purely temporary nature as it is evident that for the purposes of final partition of these provinces a detailed investigation of boundary question will be needed; and as soon as a decision involving partition has been taken for either province a boundary commission will be set up by the Governor General, the membership and terms of reference of which will be settled in consultation with those concerned.
('95', 412, 1, 6, 855867) It will be instructed to demarcate the boundaries of the two parts of the Punjab on the basis of ascertaining the contiguous majority areas of Muslims and non Muslims.
('95', 412, 1, 7, 856035) It will also be instructed to take into account other factors.
('95', 412, 1, 8, 856098) Similar instructions will be given to the Bengal Boundary Commission.
('95', 412, 1, 9, 856168) Until the report of a boundary commission has been put into effect, the provisional boundaries indicated in the Appendix will be used.
('95', 412, 2, 10, 856303) 10. The Legislative Assembly of Sind (excluding the European members) will at a special meeting also take its own decision on the alternatives in paragraph 4 above.
('95', 412, 3, 11, 856468) 11. The position of the North West Frontier Province is exceptional.
('95', 412, 3, 12, 856537) Two of the three representatives of this province are already participating in the existing Constituent Assembly.
('95', 412, 3, 13, 856651) But it is clear, in view of its geographical situation and other considerations, that if the whole or any part of the Punjab decides not to join the existing Constituent Assembly, it will be necessary to give the North West Frontier Province an opportunity to reconsider its position.
('95', 412, 3, 14, 856936) Accordingly, in such an event, a referendum will be made to the electors of the present Legislative Assembly in the North West Frontier Province to choose which of the alternatives mentioned in paragraph 4 above they wish to adopt.
('95', 412, 3, 15, 857168) The referendum will be held under the aegis of the Governor General and in consultation with the provincial Government.
('95', 412, 4, 16, 857288) 12. British Baluchistan has elected a member, but he has not taken his seat in the existing Constituent Assembly.
('95', 412, 4, 17, 857402) In view of its geographical situation, this province will also be given an opportunity to reconsider its position and to choose which of the alternatives in paragraph 4 above to adopt.
('95', 412, 4, 18, 857587) His Excellency the Governor General is examining how this can most appropriately be done.
('95', 413, 0, 1, 857677) 414 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 413, 1, 2, 857719) 13. Though Assam is predominantly a non Muslim province, the district of Sylhet which is contiguous to Bengal is predominantly Muslim.
('95', 413, 1, 3, 857854) There has been a demand that, in the event of the partition of Bengal, Sylhet should be amalgamated with the Muslim part of Bengal.
('95', 413, 1, 4, 857986) Accordingly, if it is decided that Bengal should be partitioned, a referendum will be held in Sylhet District under the aegis of the Governor General and in consultation with the Assam provincial Government to decide whether the district of Sylhet should continue to form part of Assam Province or should be amalgamated with the new province of Eastern Bengal, if that province agrees.
('95', 413, 1, 5, 858372) If the referendum results in favour of amalgamation with Eastern Bengal, a boundary commission with terms of reference similar to those for the Punjab and Bengal will be set up to demarcate the Muslim majority areas of Sylhet District and contiguous Muslim majority areas of adjoining districts, which will then be transferred to Eastern Bengal.
('95', 413, 1, 6, 858718) The rest of the Assam Province will in any case continue to participate in the proceedings of the existing Constituent Assembly.
('95', 413, 2, 7, 858847) 14. If it is decided that Bengal and the Punjab should be partitioned, it will be necessary to hold fresh elections to choose their representatives on the scale of one for every million of population according to the principle contained in the Cabinet Mission’s Plan of May 16, 1946. Similar elections will also have to be held for Sylhet in the event of it being decided that this district should form part of East Bengal.
('95', 413, 2, 8, 859271) The number of representatives to which each area would be entitled is as follows:—

('95', 413, 9, 15, 859510) 15. In accordance with the mandates given to them, the representatives of the various areas will either join the existing Constituent Assembly or form the new Constituent Assembly.
('95', 413, 10, 16, 859691) 16. Negotiations will have to be initiated as soon as possible on the administrative consequences of any partition that may have been decided upon :
('95', 413, 11, 17, 859840) (a) Between the representatives and the respective successor authorities about all subjects now dealt with by the Central Government including defence, finance and communications.
('95', 413, 12, 18, 860020) (b) Between different successor authorities and His Majesty’s Government for treaties in regard to matters arising out of the transfer of power.
('95', 413, 13, 19, 860165) (c) In the case of provinces that may be partitioned, as to the administration

('95', 414, 2, 3, 860439) 17. Agreements with tribes of the North West Frontier of India will have to be negotiated by the appropriate successor authority.
('95', 414, 3, 4, 860569) 18. His Majesty’s Government wish to make it clear that the decisions announced above relate only to British India and that their policy towards Indian States contained in the Cabinet Mission’s memorandum of 12th May, 1946, remains unchanged.
('95', 414, 4, 5, 860812) 19. In order that the successor authorities may have time to prepare themselves to take over power, it is important that all the above processes should be completed as quickly as possible.
('95', 414, 4, 6, 861001) To avoid delay, the different provinces or parts of provinces will proceed independently as far as practicable within the conditions of this plan.
('95', 414, 4, 7, 861148) The existing Constituent Assembly and the new Constituent Assembly (if formed) will proceed to frame constitutions for their respective territories; they will, of course, be free to frame their own rules.
('95', 414, 5, 8, 861353) 20. The major political parties have repeatedly emphasized their desire that there should be the earliest possible transfer of power in India.
('95', 414, 5, 9, 861496) With this desire His Majesty’s Government are in full sympathy and they are willing to anticipate the date of June, 1948, for the handing over of power by the setting up of an Independent Indian Government or Governments at an even earlier date.
('95', 414, 5, 10, 861742) Accordingly, as the most expeditious, and indeed the only practicable way of meeting this desire, his Majesty’s Government propose to introduce legislation during the current session for the transfer of power this year on a Dominion Status basis to one or two successor authorities according to the decisions taken as a result of this announcement.
('95', 414, 5, 11, 862091) This will be without prejudice to the right of the Indian Constituent Assemblies to decide in due course whether or not the part of India in respect of which they have authority will remain within the British Commonwealth.
('95', 414, 6, 12, 862314) His Excellency the Governor General will from time to time make such further announcements as may be necessary in regard to procedure or any other matters for carrying out the above arrangements.

('95', 415, 7, 9, 863154) APPENDIX IV JAWAHARLAL NEHRU’S LETTER TO VICEROY 1
('95', 415, 8, 10, 863205) 6 JANTAR MANTAR ROAD, NEW DELHI,
('95', 415, 9, 11, 863238) June 2, 1947
('95', 415, 10, 12, 863251) 1. The Congress Working Committee have considered the statement which H. M. G. propose to make tomorrow and a copy of which you were good enough to give me this morning.
('95', 415, 11, 13, 863421) 2. The proposals contained in this statement are of far reaching importance and affect the whole future of India.
('95', 415, 11, 14, 863535) These envisage the possibility of certain parts of India seceding from the rest.
('95', 415, 12, 15, 863616) 3. As you know, the Congress has consistently upheld that the unity of India should be maintained.
('95', 415, 12, 16, 863715) Ever since its inception, the Congress has worked towards the realization of a free and united India.
('95', 415, 12, 17, 863817) Any proposal, therefore, which might bring about separation of a part of India from the rest is painful to contemplate and, in the opinion of the Congress, is harmful to all the parties concerned.
('95', 415, 12, 18, 864014) Such a proposal would normally have to be considered by the All India Congress Committee.
('95', 415, 12, 19, 864104) The Working Committee would make its recommendations to that Committee, but the final decision would rest with the All India Congress Committee, or the full session of the Congress itself.
('95', 415, 13, 20, 864293) 4. We have realized, however, that in the peculiar and abnormal situation of today it is not possible to delay matters and decisions have to be reached rapidly.
('95', 415, 13, 21, 864454) There has been far too much uncertainty in the country and this has led to instability and to violence on a large scale.
('95', 415, 13, 22, 864575) We have also appreciated that the negotiations that have been going on for some time between you and [the] Indian leaders had of necessity to be secret.
('95', 415, 14, 23, 864728) 5. My Committee considered the principles underlying the present proposals about a month ago and generally accepted them.
('95', 415, 14, 24, 864850) This acceptance was conveyed to you in paragraph 12 of the letter dated 1st May, 1947, which Shri
('95', 415, 15, 25, 864948) 1Vide “Speech at Congress Working Committee Meeting”, 2 6 1947
('95', 416, 0, 1, 865011) VOL. 95 : 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY 1947 417
('95', 416, 1, 2, 865052) Jawaharlal Nehru wrote to you.
('95', 416, 2, 3, 865083) 6. As we have stated on many occasions, we accepted in its entirety the Cabinet Mission’s Statement of 16th May, 1946 as will as the sub sequent interpretation thereof dated 6th December, 1946. We have indeed been acting in accordance with it and the Constituent Assembly which was formed in terms of the Cabinet Mission’s Plan has been functioning for nearly six months.
('95', 416, 2, 4, 865455) We are still prepared to adhere to that Plan.
('95', 416, 2, 5, 865501) In view, however, of subsequent events and the situation today, we are willing to accept as a variation of that Plan the proposals now being made.
('95', 416, 3, 6, 865648) 7. I do not wish to enter into any detailed examination of the proposed statement of H. M. G. It has been produced after considerable consultation and I am desired to say by my Committee that we are prepared to accept it and to recommend to the All India Congress Committee to do likewise.
('95', 416, 3, 7, 865938) We do so in the earnest hope that this will mean a settlement.
('95', 416, 3, 8, 866001) We feel that the situation in India, political and economic, as well as com munal, demands more than ever a peaceful approach to all our problems.
('95', 416, 3, 9, 866148) These problems cannot be solved by methods of violence, and there can be no submission to such methods.
('95', 416, 4, 10, 866252) 8. While we are willing to accept the proposals made by H. M. G., my Committee desire to emphasize that they are doing go in order to achieve a final settlement.
('95', 416, 4, 11, 866414) This is dependent on the acceptance of the proposals by the Muslim League and a clear understanding that no further claims will be put forward.
('95', 416, 4, 12, 866558) There has been enough misunderstanding in the past and in order to avoid this in the future it is necessary to have explicit statements in writing in regard to these proposals.
('95', 416, 5, 13, 866735) 9. We believe as fully as ever in a united India.
('95', 416, 5, 14, 866785) The unity we aim at is not that of compulsion but of friendship and co operation.
('95', 416, 5, 15, 866867) We earnestly trust that when present passions have subsided our problems will be viewed in their proper perspective and a willing union of all parts of India will result therefrom.
('95', 416, 6, 16, 867048) 10. There are some matters, however, to which I should like to draw your attention.
('95', 416, 6, 17, 867132) My Committee realize that the proposals being put forward may result in injury to the Sikhs unless great care is taken and their peculiar position in the Punjab is fully appreciated.
('95', 416, 6, 18, 867315) We are aware that H. M. G. and you are anxious to protect all legitimate Sikh interests.
('95', 416, 6, 19, 867404) The matter will have to be considered by the Boundary Commission provided for and we earnestly trust that all other factors, apart from population, will be taken fully into consideration.
('95', 416, 6, 20, 867592) The Sikhs have played a vital role in developing a considerable part of the Punjab.
('95', 416, 6, 21, 867676) They have been pioneers in the canal areas and have converted by their labours the desert into the richest part of the Punjab.
('95', 416, 6, 22, 867803) It has been made clear in the document that the national partition is of a purely temporary character and the final boundaries will be determined by the Boundary Commission.
('95', 417, 0, 1, 867977) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 417, 1, 2, 868019) 11. In the last sentence of paragraph 9 it is stated that “until the report of the Boundary Commission has been put into effect, the provisional boundary as indicated in the Appendix will be used.” It is not quite clear to what this refers and what the use will be.
('95', 417, 1, 3, 868285) It is well known that the notional division ignores other important factors and that the Sikhs are distressed by it.
('95', 417, 1, 4, 868402) If any further use is made of this notional division for ad ministrative or other purposes, this will inevitably affect the final division and will give rise to a great deal of apprehension in the minds of the Sikhs.
('95', 417, 1, 5, 868619) We would, therefore, urge you not to apply that notional division for any administrative purpose during the interim period.
('95', 417, 1, 6, 868743) This would be in keeping with the spirit of the document and with what you conveyed to us this morning.
('95', 417, 2, 7, 868847) 12. In paragraph 11 of the statement reference is made to a referendum in the N. W. F. Province.
('95', 417, 2, 8, 868944) There has been a growing demand in the Province for independence and subsequent decision as to their relation with the rest of India.
('95', 417, 2, 9, 869078) The referendum should also provide for this.
('95', 417, 3, 10, 869123) 13. In paragraph 20 of the statement, which, we are told, is an addition to the original draft, the last sentence refers to the right of the Constituent Assemblies to decide in due course whether or not India or any part of it will remain within the British Commonwealth.
('95', 417, 3, 11, 869395) It seems to us extremely undesirable and likely to lead to friction if the relations of Britain with the Indian Union and the seceding parts of it are on differential basis.
('95', 417, 3, 12, 869569) We should, therefore, like to make it clear that we cannot be consenting parties to any such development.
('95', 417, 4, 13, 869675) 14. In view of the importance of the proposals and decisions being made, my Committee intend to convene a meeting of the All India Congress Committee at an early date.
('95', 417, 4, 14, 869843) They propose to recommend the acceptance generally of the statement of H.M.G. as a settlement of our political and communal problems.
('95', 417, 5, 15, 869977) HIS EXCELLENCY VISCOUNT MOUNTBATTEN O F BURMA

('95', 418, 5, 8, 870988) APPENDIX VI LORD MOUNTBATTEN’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW WITH GANDHIJI 1
('95', 418, 6, 9, 871053) June 6, 1947
('95', 418, 7, 10, 871066) I had received an urgent letter from Krishna Menon warning me that Mr. Gandhi was in a very unhappy and emotional mood, and that some of the Congress leaders feared he might denounce the plan and its acceptance at his prayer meeting that evening.
('95', 418, 8, 11, 871313) I immediately sent a message inviting Mr. Gandhi to come and see me at any time before the prayer meeting.
('95', 418, 8, 12, 871420) He arrived at 6 with the prayer meeting due at 7 p.
('95', 418, 9, 13, 871472) He was indeed in a very upset mood and began by saying how unhappy he was.
('95', 418, 10, 14, 871547) I replied immediately that whilst I could quite understand and indeed shared his upset feelings at seeing the united India he had worked for all his life apparently destroyed by the new plan, I hoped to convince him that this plan was nevertheless the only possible course.
('95', 418, 11, 15, 871821) I told him that although many newspapers had christened it “The Mountbatten Plan”, they should really have christened it “The Gandhi Plan”, since all the salient ingredients were suggested to me by him.
('95', 418, 11, 16, 872024) I enumerated these as follows:
('95', 418, 12, 17, 872055) (a) Mr. Gandhi advised me to try and get the Cabinet Mission Plan or any other plan retaining the unity of India accepted by all the leaders provided it did not involve coercion or violence.
('95', 418, 12, 18, 872246) I had bent every effort to follow the first part of his advice; but when no agreement could be reached I had followed the second part of his advice and not insisted on a plan which would involve coercion with its attendant risk of violence.
('95', 418, 13, 19, 872487) (b) Mr. Gandhi had advised me to leave the choice of their own future to the Indian people.
('95', 418, 13, 20, 872579) It was therefore he who gave me the idea for letting the Provinces choose, and the method proposed seemed the simplest and fairest way of carrying out
('95', 418, 14, 21, 872730) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 6 6 1947
('95', 419, 0, 1, 872773) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 419, 1, 2, 872815) his suggestion.
('95', 419, 2, 3, 872831) (c) Mr. Gandhi had told me that the British should quit India and transfer power as soon as possible and not later than the end of this year.
('95', 419, 2, 4, 872973) I told him 1 that this had been the most difficult of all of his ideas to carry out, and I was very proud to have found a solution.
('95', 419, 3, 5, 873105) (d) I told him that I had understood that in his earlier days he had not been averse to Dominion Status.
('95', 419, 3, 6, 873210) Mr. Gandhi was kind enough to say that this was indeed so, and that even during the war he had expressed himself as not being against it; and he later sent me an extract from Harijan dated 16th December 1939, in which appeared the words: “Similarly, I have said to a friend that if Dominion Status was offered, I should take it, and expect to carry India with me.”
('95', 419, 4, 7, 873575) Note: I subsequently reported this conversation to both Mr. Krishna and Mr. V. P. Menon, and asked them to work on similar lines in talking to Mr. Gandhi.
('95', 419, 4, 8, 873730) Both reported that the line I had taken had been remarkably successful, since Mr. Gandhi now felt that I had honestly tried to follow his advice, and that he had taken a far greater part in shaping the future of India than had at first sight appeared to him from the way the plan was worded.

('95', 419, 6, 11, 874115) APPENDIX VII EXCERPTS FROM JAWAHARLAL NEHRU’S NOTE 2
('95', 419, 7, 12, 874168) June 8, 1947
('95', 419, 8, 13, 874181) “There is no doubt that the Governor and many of the Frontier officials have not only not co operated with the Provincial Government but have actually sometimes obstructed its work.
('95', 419, 8, 14, 874363) In any event they are nearly all leaving the Frontier soon and we must proceed on that basis.
('95', 419, 8, 15, 874457) There is no particular point in our raising this issue of en masse withdrawal now.”
('95', 419, 9, 16, 874541) The question of referendum… came up “not exactly on the Pakistan issue” but in view of certain changes and developments in the all India situation.
('95', 419, 9, 17, 874689) it was .
('95', 419, 9, 18, 874698) stated that in view of this new situation it would be advisable to have a referendum in the Frontier in order to determine to which Constituent Assembly the N. W. F. P. desired to belong.
('95', 419, 9, 19, 874886) The proposal, therefore, was not just meant for the N. W. F. P., but became part of a larger plan which provided for referendum in the N. W. F. P., Baluchistan and Sylhet.
('95', 419, 9, 20, 875058) It seemed a logical and reasonable proposal apart from the particular circumstances prevailing.
('95', 419, 10, 21, 875154) 1 The source has ‘me’ 2 Vide “Foreword to “Charles Freer Andrews”, Draft”, 9 6 1947
('95', 420, 0, 1, 875238) VOL. 95 : 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY 1947 421
('95', 420, 1, 2, 875279) “But in all likelihood parts of Bengal and the Punjab will decide in favour of secession and so we may take it as almost granted that the question will arise for decision in the N. W. F. P. The present position is that the British Government and the Viceroy are definitely committed to this referendum.
('95', 420, 1, 3, 875582) Some of us are also more or less committed….
('95', 420, 1, 4, 875627) The question of referendum, therefore, appears to be a settled one and it is not quite clear how we can get out of it.
('95', 420, 1, 5, 875746) For the Viceroy it is still more difficult.
('95', 420, 1, 6, 875790) Any change in the plan… may even lead to conflict on a bit scale.
('95', 420, 1, 7, 875856) We may, therefore, take it as a settled fact that a referendum will take place.”
('95', 420, 2, 8, 875937) In order to ensure peaceful conditions during the referendum, Pandit Nehru explained, it was proposed that “it should be organized by British military officers to be imported from outside….
('95', 420, 2, 9, 876127) The Provincial Government would be closely associated with the machinery for this referendum”.
('95', 420, 2, 10, 876222) Normally speaking, Pandit Nehru did not think that there was much chance of “any big violent conflict”.
('95', 420, 3, 11, 876326) The proposal that the people of the Frontier should be allowed to vote for sovereign independence raised certain difficulties: “The Viceroy said he can only agree if the parties agree….
('95', 420, 3, 12, 876512) It may also introduce an element of confusion in the voting when there issues are before the voter….
('95', 420, 3, 13, 876613) Votes may well be split.”
('95', 420, 4, 14, 876639) As for the suggestion that the Frontier Congress should keep out of the referendum, Pandit Nehru argued that it would mean “accepting the Muslim League’s dominance in the N. W. F. P.—in effect a surrender to the Muslim League agitation”.
('95', 420, 5, 15, 876877) “Whether it will lead to peaceful conditions or not, it is difficult to say.
('95', 420, 5, 16, 876954) But I imagine that any such waiver or surrender is even more likely to lead to conflict and bloodshed because the Muslim League would celebrate this surrender as a great victory for the League.
('95', 420, 5, 17, 877148) They would be justified then in claiming that the present Ministry does not represent the bulk of the population.
('95', 420, 5, 18, 877262) It seems difficult for the Provincial Ministry to continue after a decision has been given against them by a referendum or by a waiver of referendum.
('95', 420, 5, 19, 877412) Possibly, the question would immediately arise of another election to the Provincial Legislature.
('95', 420, 5, 20, 877510) Having avoided the referendum .
('95', 420, 5, 21, 877542) we do not avoid trouble and difficulty and the Provincial Ministry cannot continue.
('95', 420, 5, 22, 877626) The election takes palace anyhow with all its possible evil consequences.
('95', 420, 5, 23, 877700) The only other course is a peaceful submission to the Pakistan idea, and I doubt very much if most of the Pathans will agree to it.”
('95', 420, 6, 24, 877833) Pandit Nehru concluded .
('95', 420, 6, 25, 877858) to keep away from the referendum “would be to ensure a wrong decision” and that too “not by the ordinary democratic process but by private arrangement”.
('95', 420, 7, 26, 878011) “This seems to me a very dangerous procedure to follow both in regard to avoidance of violence and regarding our own future in the N. W. F. P. To fight democratically and to be defeated does not weaken us for long and we can renew the struggle in other ways later.
('95', 420, 7, 27, 878276) But to give up without a struggle means a certain lack of
('95', 421, 0, 1, 878334) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('95', 421, 1, 2, 878376) integrity through fear of consequences and leads to the collapse of the organization which was unable to face the issue.
('95', 421, 2, 3, 878497) In view of all these circumstances, it seems to me that the only right course is for us to accept the referendum and to prepare for it with all our strength.
('95', 421, 2, 4, 878655) We have a good chance of winning it.
('95', 421, 2, 5, 878692) We should go to the referendum on the cry that we want the largest measure of freedom and independence in the Frontier.
('95', 421, 2, 6, 878812) This is not a straight issue of sovereign independence but a slight variation of that theme which should prove helpful.
('95', 421, 2, 7, 878932) In effect, after Pakistan comes into being in Western Punjab, and the Frontier is cut off from India, the N. W. F. P. will inevitably have, because of this cutting off and other reasons, a very great deal of autonomy and independence.
('95', 421, 2, 8, 879167) If there is risk in this course, there are far greater risks of bloodshed in other courses.
('95', 421, 2, 9, 879259) The course suggested is a brave, frank course of accepting battle peacefully.
('95', 421, 2, 10, 879337) To give up the battle, when final decisions are being taken, will result in deep psychological injury to our people.”
('95', 421, 3, 11, 879455) To some extent he (Mountbatten) is naturally bound by the past and the present set up; but he is trying his best to go ahead in the right direction.
('95', 421, 3, 12, 879604) He realizes the difficulties of the Frontier problem and wants to do everything in his power to solve them.
('95', 421, 3, 13, 879712) I think he will prove helpful.
('95', 421, 3, 14, 879743) He is convinced, however, that in the peculiar condi tions that are arising in India now owing to possible secession of some parts, a chance must be given to the Frontier people to decide themselves by means of a referendum.
('95', 421, 3, 15, 879968) He is definitely committed himself to this and he cannot get out of it without grave injury to his own prestige and impartiality.
('95', 421, 3, 16, 880098) He would probably prefer to resign than to face such a situation.”

('95', 421, 5, 18, 880209) APPENDIX VIII TELEGRAM FROM C. P. RAMASWAMY IYER 1
('95', 421, 6, 19, 880260) Will you allow me to protest against erroneous statements made by you at your prayer meeting yesterday relying on inaccurate reports.
('95', 421, 6, 20, 880394) There was no banning of meetings in Travancore except where breaches of peace were apprehended and a number of meetings have been actually held.
('95', 421, 6, 21, 880539) Fourteen persons alone have been arrested throughout the State, of whom eight have been ordered to be released.
('95', 421, 6, 22, 880651) Those who were arrested were dealt with for defying the Magistrate’s orders in places where breach of peace was apprehended.
('95', 421, 6, 23, 880776) There was no lathi charge anywhere.
('95', 421, 7, 24, 880812) You have asked the Indian States not to rely on the British.
('95', 421, 7, 25, 880873) It is not Indian States that are now relying on the British Government, but the Congress and I am
('95', 421, 8, 26, 880971) 1Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 14 6 1947
('95', 422, 0, 1, 881015) VOL. 95 : 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY 1947 423
('95', 422, 1, 2, 881056) aware that the British Government are more anxious to secure the consent of the Congress to Dominion Status than to befriend the States.
('95', 422, 1, 3, 881193) I wish to assure you that we are at least as conscious of our need for self reliance as you are.
('95', 422, 1, 4, 881290) You will find out for yourself that the people of Travancore are, as an overwhelming majority, in favour of the stand for independence.
('95', 422, 1, 5, 881426) May I also make it clear that this independence is wholly consistent with close relations as regards defence, foreign affairs and all matters of common concern with the rest of India.
('95', 422, 2, 6, 881610) The needless threats indulged in by Pandit Nehru are really uncalled for because no Indian State wishes to enter into any relations with foreign and hostile powers against the interest of India.
('95', 422, 2, 7, 881805) I hope you will persuade yourself and your followers to credit those who differ from you with as much patriotism as you claim for yourself.
('95', 422, 2, 8, 881945) With regard to the audacity attributed to Indian States by you, I may invite your attention to the statement of Sir Stafford Cripps at the Press Conference on May 16, 1946, in which he said: “It is not necessary for me to state that a contract or arrangement of this kind cannot be handed over to a third party without the consent of the States.
('95', 422, 2, 9, 882291) They will, therefore, become wholly independent.” On July 18, 1946, both Lord Pethick Lawrence and Sir Stafford Cripps have stated: “As for States, they need have no anxiety.
('95', 422, 2, 10, 882466) It is for them to agree to come in or not as they choose” Lastly the present Secretary of State on June 3, 1947, stated that after the transfer of power, States should be free to choose their own future and that British Paramountcy would end.
('95', 422, 2, 11, 882709) The course left open to them would be autonomy or affiliation with either Pakistan or Hindustan.
('95', 422, 3, 12, 882806) The audacity, if any, is on the part of those statesmen under whose aegis the Congress is now embarking on Dominion Status.
('95', 422, 3, 13, 882930) The threats of Pandit Nehru and his reliance on world powers, including Britain, to help him to implement those threats will no doubt be considered by Lord Listowel and Sir Stafford Cripps, but it is difficult to see how they can go behind their own statements.
('95', 422, 3, 14, 883192) I note with intense regret that you have not yet withdrawn the false allegation that I have asked Travancoreans who do not agree to independence to quit the State in spite of my denial and the telegram addressed to you by twelve journalists who attended the Press Conference.
('95', 422, 3, 15, 883468) The B. B. C. has repeated the calumny this morning evidently taking shelter under your statements.

('95', 423, 1, 2, 883630) APPENDIX IX
('95', 423, 2, 3, 883642) LORD MOUNTBATTEN’S NOTE ON INTERVIEW WITH GANDHIJI AND M. A. JINNAH
('95', 423, 3, 4, 883710) June 17, 1947
('95', 423, 4, 5, 883724) I saw Mr. Gandhi from 10 to 11 a.
('95', 423, 4, 6, 883758) The main topic of the discussions was the referendum.
('95', 423, 4, 7, 883812) He still wanted Mr. Jinnah to go and see the N. W. F. P. Government leaders to [talk to] them as suggested in the statement he had prepared with Lord Ismay.
('95', 423, 5, 8, 883969) He was most dissatisfied at Mr. Jinnah’s stipulation about no Congress interference; and he still wanted me to urge Mr. Jinnah to go, as their correspondence had come to a full stop.
('95', 423, 6, 9, 884152) I asked him whether he would agree to see Mr. Jinnah right away, and on obtaining his agreement, sent a telephone message to Mr. Jinnah asking if he would come earlier than his original time, to see Mr. Gandhi.
('95', 423, 6, 10, 884363) Mr. Jinnah came at 11.0 a .
('95', 423, 6, 11, 884391) and joined the meeting until 12 noon.
('95', 423, 7, 12, 884429) Both these great men spoke in such low voices that they could not hear each other, so I had to move their chairs close together.
('95', 423, 7, 13, 884558) After a good deal of mutual recrimination about their correspondence, I finally solved the problem by suggesting that since Abdul Ghaffar Khan had been invested with plenary authority by the Frontier Ministry, Mr Jinnah should take advantage of his presence in Delhi to meet him here.
('95', 423, 7, 14, 884843) Both leaders seemed to think this a good idea, but Mr. Gandhi said that Abdul Ghaffar Khan was most mistrustful of Mr. Jinnah and would not come unless he received a written invitation.
('95', 423, 7, 15, 885029) Mr. Jinnah said he had frequently extended verbal invitations, and that if Abdul Ghaffar Khan was not prepared to accept these, the certainly had no intention of sending him a written invitation.
('95', 423, 7, 16, 885225) After this wrangle had gone on for some time, I solved the difficulty by offering to invite all concerned to meet me at 7.45 the same evening.
('95', 423, 7, 17, 885368) Both accepted and honour was satisfied.
('95', 423, 7, 18, 885408) Unfortunately, Abdul Ghaffar Khan had an engagement 100 miles outside Delhi, and although he was due back between 6.0 p.
('95', 423, 7, 19, 885529) and 7.0 p.
('95', 423, 7, 20, 885540) m., he did not get back in time for the meeting.
('95', 423, 7, 21, 885589) I personally telephoned Mr. Jinnah and Raj Kumari Amrit Kaur, Mr. Gandhi’s secretary, and got them to agree to a meeting with Abdul Ghaffar Khan at the Viceroy’s House the following day, under the chairmanship of Lord Ismay.
('95', 423, 8, 22, 885814) Before Mr. Jinnah’s arrival, I mentioned to Mr. Gandhi that I believed a question was likely to be asked in the House concerning the position of those Indian States who declared their independence.
('95', 423, 8, 23, 886012) I informed him that on being asked this
('95', 424, 0, 1, 886052) VOL. 95 : 30 APRIL, 1947 6 JULY 1947 425
('95', 424, 1, 2, 886093) question, in my Press Conference, I had replied to the effect that States would not be allowed Dominion Status and that the question of separate negotiations with States was a hypothetical question which had not yet arisen.
('95', 424, 1, 3, 886317) If I received such a request, I would refer it to H. M. G. I pointed out that Hyderabad had a Trade Commissioner in London, and I was sure that H.M.G. could not be expected to cut off trade relations with Hyderabad.
('95', 424, 2, 4, 886533) Mr. Gandhi begged me on no account to make any statement in Delhi, and, if possible, to make no statement about this question until he returned.
('95', 424, 2, 5, 886678) Since he wished to continue the discussion with me and I was unable to do so, I invited him to see Lord Ismay and arrange for an immediate meeting.

('95', 424, 5, 10, 886949) APPENDIX X LETTER FROM LORD MOUNTBATTEN TO HARI SINGH 1
('95', 424, 6, 11, 887005) June 26, 1947
('95', 424, 7, 12, 887019) I am writing to tell Your Highness that I have had a talk with both Mahatma Gandhi and Pandit Nehru, who are both still anxious to visit Kashmir.
('95', 424, 7, 13, 887165) I pointed out to them that any visit from a big Congress leader in which speeches were made could not fail to cause the League to send speakers of the order of Mr. Jinnah to counter their propaganda.
('95', 424, 7, 14, 887365) This would in effect produce the electioneering atmosphere which you so rightly wish to avoid, since, as you pointed out to me, there has been no bloodshed up to date and only violent political speeches could now bring about the bloodshed.
('95', 424, 8, 15, 887605) Mr. Gandhi tells me that Pandit Nehru is prepared to forgo his visit if he (Mr. Gandhi) goes instead.
('95', 424, 9, 16, 887707) I am therefore writing this at Mr. Gandhi’s request…to suggest that you should agree to his visit in the near future and make things as easy as possible for him.
('95', 424, 9, 17, 887869) He has given me his firm assurance that he will make no political speeches or carry out any form of propaganda.
('95', 424, 9, 18, 887981) The object of his visit would be to see Madame Abdullah; and, if you granted permission (but only if you did grant him permission), he would like to see Sheikh Abdullah.
('95', 424, 9, 19, 888151) He would like to meet the people in general way, but has no desire to address them or to collect large crowds.
('95', 424, 10, 20, 888262) May I suggest that Your Highness or your Prime Minister should communicate direct with him to save time.
('95', 424, 10, 21, 888367) Gandhiji’s Correspondence with the Government, 1944 47, p.

('95', 425, 1, 2, 888514) APPENDIX XI EXTRACT FROM MINUTES OF VICEROY’S 48TH STAFF MEETING 1
('95', 425, 2, 3, 888581) June 28, 1947 His Excellency The Viceroy read out a letter which he had received that morning from Mr. Gandhi.
('95', 425, 2, 4, 888692) He stated that throughout this letter Mr. Gandhi had completely misinterpreted what he had said at his meeting two days previously.
('95', 425, 2, 5, 888824) In fact, he had told Mr. Gandhi that he was finding increasing difficulty in helping to get matters connected with Partition settled.
('95', 425, 2, 6, 888958) He had pointed out that it was for Congress not a question of fair play to ensure that the various issues were settled speedily, but of sheer expediency.
('95', 425, 2, 7, 889112) If Congress took the line that they were not going to help, Mr. Jinnah would point out to the world at large the Congress’s acceptance of the Statement of 3rd June had not been honest.
('95', 425, 2, 8, 889297) He had told Mr. Gandhi that it would be very foolish of Congress to give Mr. Jinnah any excuse for not being ready to take over power on 15th August.
('95', 425, 2, 9, 889447) He had assured Mr. Gandhi that he intended in any event to hand over power on that date, but had explained that Congress would be put in a very poor position in the eyes of the world if they made it difficult for Mr. Jinnah to take over.
('95', 425, 2, 10, 889685) Mr. Gandhi had stated that the words “fair play” did not exist in any Hindustani dialect.
('95', 425, 2, 11, 889775) He (The Viceroy) had reiterated that he was not expecting or demanding fair play; all that he was requesting was a degree of common sense so that Congress would not put themselves in the position of wrecking an agreement which had been honourably reached.
('95', 425, 3, 12, 890031) His Excellency the Viceroy directed P. S. V. to draft, for his approval, a reply to Mr. Gandhi’s letter.
('95', 425, 4, 13, 890136) From a copy: India Office Library and Records
('95', 425, 5, 14, 890182) 1Vide “Letter to Lord mountatten”, 27/28 6 1947
